review_title: Denver Rampservice, looking forward to merger
pros: The employees in all work groups are the best people I have ever worked with.  Employee groups continue to try their best to work together, despite pay-cuts, layoffs, and news of senior management bonuses (while we are taking pay-cuts).  I am proud to work with "My United Family" and am inspired by my co-workers, of course I do not consider senior management part of this family.  The merger with Continental is also inspiring, as the new CEO also looks at his company as an inter-related group (family).  The pride is still there, under the muck of the past couple years.  With the right leadership, the new United/Continental could be a great place to work, providing the best airline service in the world.  Last, but not least, the medical/dental and flight benefits are fantastic.
cons: As stated above, it is very dispiriting to take a pay-cut as senior management is giving itself raises and bonuses.  You get the idea that senior management considers themselves above the rest of the company.  Shouldn't everyone participate in compromises to help support our company?  I have also witnessed many actions that seem to hurt morale, when the workers actually need more action to promote morale and show support for the hardships that they have had to endure (pay-cuts, lay-offs, hours cut, or relocation to maintain full-time employment).

pros: Travel benefits... but unfortunately, you will not be able to afford to travel due to low wages.  Decent scheduling flexibility after about 15 years of seniority.  I honestly cannot think of many good reasons to work for this company.  My advice to a friend... AVOID!
cons: You think you are going to see the world, but what you are really going to see is a lot of airport hotels, and very short layovers.  Exhaustingly long work days up to 17 hours.  Diminishing work rules, and benefits. Low wages. The first five years of employment you will probably live below the poverty line.  The wages have basically remained the same since 1979.  If you think you can survive on 1979 wages... go for it.  Most people remedy this by living in an apartment with too many roommates.  Incompetent management.  Management seems to have actual contempt for it's own employees.  They begin treating you like a five year old the minute you arrive at their training center.  Management will treat you with a complete lack of respect.  My best advice is to avoid the airline industry altogether.  I have a bachelors degree, and after 23 years of employment, I found myself earning about $39,000 a year... but I was flying my ass off.  You will never get ahead earning this kind of money, and there is little hope of the wages increasing.  My salary has actually been cut twice in the last five years.  It's supposed to go up, not down.  AVOID!

review_title: If you stay long enough and move around, you will learn and love the airline industry
pros: It you love the airline business this is the place to be. It is a large airline which grapples with all the problems of small and large carriers. Travel benefits are excellent and pay at the higher levels is good too. Given enough time, there is opportunity to move around into different functions and also work on international projects.
cons: The culture is very internally focused, people don't engage with each other socially, unless they have been working together for many (over 10 years). This makes it harder for new comers to break in.  Middle management can be very "heads down" focused and conflict averse to a fault. While the atmosphere is collegiate, middle management does not take a strong stands and is usually passive resistive.  Senior management tends to be more aggressive, but tends to revolve a lot and admission in to senior levels tends to be from the outside, rather than from within the company.  Middle management tends to be "old hands" who sometimes simply wait for the next change over to happen.

review_title: Great company to work for 'in theory', potentially great 'in practice.'

- CEO Jeff Smisek is very visible and seems genuine.
- Because of merger, opportunities tend to be more merit-based than tenure-based...but could still improve.
- Back-office policy seems to becoming more flexible (i.e. relaxed dress code, work from home, etc.)
- I belief corporate culture is trending upward.
cons:
- "...because that's the way we've always done it" is still acceptable reason.
- Vertical hierarchy cripples back-office and front-office operations. I believe leadership recognizes this which is a plus, but is clueless on how to fix it.
- Most innovative idea to come from HR seems to be electronic pay stubs.
- ...don't laugh Corp Comm, I'm not sure you know what the phrase "outside-the-box" means.
- Would like to see more horizontal learning opportunities.

You only get paid for flight time, so (and this happens all the time) you could have a 14 hour work day and only get paid for about 7 hours (of flight time). On top of that, since you’re on 24 hour call, you could go to bed and get called at 10 and get a call at 1am for one of these 14 hour work days. I feel like this shouldn’t even be legal and it took a toll on my physical and mental health very quickly. Again, I could write a book on why this is literally the worst job in the Job market, but I’m going to keep it short and sweet.

United has the potential to be a great company but the corporate culture needs to change from the top and the way down.

cons: Lots of running around because of so many flights going in and out.  A very tiring job.  The flying benefits were great if you like to travel. The training was also very intense with a lot to learn in just a week.  If you don't catch on quickly to airline computer lingo, you're in trouble.  Lots of my co-workers were let go after the final exam.  And you don't get to bid your shift.. so you have to take whatever they assign you.

review_title: It's OK. But could be better.
pros: Travel benefits are nice to have.  If you like irregular time off, in blocks of days, then it can be a good job.
cons: Pretty high stress over time, and a sense that the company doesn't take advantage of its opportunities...  and in fact squanders most of them.  This could have been and should have been the greatest airline in the world, but it has thrown away great assets and opportunities, and spent the years after 9-11 diminishing its employees rather than building them up.  At the end of the day, I question whether the compensation is actually worth the stress of constantly being at someone else's beck-and-call, and being truly uprooted and gone for at least half of your life.

The general public can be quite demanding.  This business is fickle and subject to change with oil prices and weather dominating.

review_title: United is the right place for my career
pros: It was once mentioned to me that "if you can't find the right ob for you here, you won't find it anywhere.". I don't have a job at UA, I have a career. There are definitely growth opportunities.  The focus on developing our leaders is positive for the new culture. Being a part of a strong, stable company that is redesigning so many processes and policies is challenging and exciting.  I truly believe I make a difference and it gets noticed by my peers and managers.
cons: With so many unions in the company, there's a large sense of entitlement because seniority means more than performance.  This hurts customer service, at times.  There is still a lot to do with the merger and it's creating burn out for those that have been involved the past 2 years.  Joining the team now is a great time, though. A lot of the major pain has already taken place,

pros: An airline is a complex matrix organization that is constantly changing and improving, which provides ample opportunities to learn new skills and grow as a professional. I work in a fun group with highly motivated individuals who also value work/life balance. The culture is evolving due to the merger with Continental, so that in combination with some deep industry shift, I can confidently say that United is a great company to work and looking forward to a long career here. Not to mention the travel perks to fly anywhere in the world last minute are unmatched in any other industry.
cons: The organization is quite large with employees spread across multiple offices around the country - as you can imagine with any large company, there are certain things that just take longer because of certain policies or procedures. Any proposed improvements or programs need to be properly vetted as they can impact multiple divisions throughout the company.

pros:
Great culture of teamwork.  Incidents in the last few years have been used as a pivoting point and management and workgroups are truly trying to make this the best place for our customers, the employees, and (of course) shareholders.

Management treats me and my coworkers with respect and conducts regular listening sessions and company-wide surveys to gauge they are doing and what can be improved.  Not only do they listen, they actually implement the advice they receive from the frontline employees.

My position offers industry-leading compensation and benefits in many areas.  Benefits that are unique to the industry include worldwide travel which is excellent if you're looking for adventure.  Excellent retirement contribution from the company.

I thoroughly enjoy working here and would recommend a career with United Airlines to individuals looking for a position in the aviation industry.
cons: United seems to have overcome the mistakes of the previous management team and is moving in the correct direction.  That being said we have set lofty expectations for Wall Street over the next several years.  I believe we can achieve these goals, but if we are not successful I believe it would be a true loss to United if the current management team is forced out.

MCO United Airlines Management was extremely unprofessional. They treat their employees with little to no respect.  The uniforms do not match with other co-workers even though you pay for a uniform.  United will throw your lunch or snack in the trash without asking, if they feel like they do not like you. You are NOT allowed to use their break room for lunch. Only certain employees get better treatment. United Agents will talk rude to customers. Customers wait at the kiosk for a long periods of time before checking in because United agents are too busy engaging in conversation with each other. Also, they are  ageist. No one between the ages of 18- 35 Are Actual United Agents. Ages 18-35 only throw Bags. The employees that throw Bags are paid minimum wage. They have to work 15 hours or more to makeup for the minimum amount of money they get paid. They hire 18-35 employees left and right through a third party. They are the WORST company I have EVER worked for in my life. I never have written a review for a company
 But if they don't change management, there will be a lot of customer complaints. I just don't see how they call themselves UNITED. Far from it. The irony.

pros: The hope that United will once again be the airline that passengers want to fly, employees want to work for and shareholders want to own.
cons:
Unfortunately United Airlines senior management has no concern for passengers, shareholders or employees. Their one focus has been to complete a merger with another airline. This merger will benefit no one - not passengers, not employees, nor shareholders - only Glenn Tilton and a few at the top that will stand to walk away with millions. 
Most recently they are cutting back routes, planes and employees to size the airline appropriately for a merger with Continental Airlines. This is being done ahead of the merger so that all the cuts will be complete when the merger plan is presented to the justice department. United Airlines will then tell the justice department that there will be no employee cutbacks due to a merger with Continental. They will have  already been done. 
Additionally, many of the jobs - mechanics, customer service, pilots have been outsourced to an extraordinary degree, partly to be used as a bargaining chip when contract negotiations take place. 
United Airlines senior management has a particular disdain for it's employees, startlingIy even beyond pure business dealings and to a personal level.

review_title: GREAT place if you can afford to not work too much.
pros:
If you aren't interested in respect for a job well done and can afford to not need to work, then this is the job for you.  It's easy and it's fun.  You will see the world and have a great time doing it.

Benefits are outstanding, medical, dental and vision.  Standby flights encompass the world at a very inexpensive price.
cons:
You will never increase your position by doing a job well.  You increase your standing at United by getting old.   The longer you stay, the better your seniority gets.  It's a simple process but doesn't encourage hard work.  

Management treats employees horribly, trying to constantly figure a way to fire you.  

They change the rules but hide them at the same time.  You must pay attention to the rules or risk beginning the discipline process.  Don't even think about getting sick.  They want paperwork for everything.  One missed trip and they start adding 'points' against you to use in their discipline process.  Very juvenile experience.

cons: Reserve life in beginning is very very hard. if you don't live in base then commute is hassle. pay is very low in beginning while on reserve. if you not a second language speaker be ready for 5-10 years or even longer on reserve if you get hired in 2017 or later.  always watch your back specially if some one write you up or your supervisor don't like you because you are just a number to United. review_title: This is one of the worst employers on the US
pros: Flight benefits are the only good thing about the company. However, they pat low so employee are not able to utilize their benefits because they can not afford to lodging or transportation once they fly someplace.
cons:
The management at this company is very incompetent. People are picked for management level jobs. They seem to know who they want to promote based on  personal relationships so the interview processes are just formalities. As a result, the best candidate are not promoted so you tend to have people in positions that are incompetent or lack skills for their positions.

Plus, HR is generally used for recruiting/hiring. They do not get involved in the performance process or skills analysis. There is not documentation of people's skill-level. 

The other bad thing about this company is that people generally stay with the company because of the flight benefits. They are low-performers and tend to bring moral down of new and hard-working employees.

pros: In a society we live  today it is good to see a company that with it's employees (even in this size) can create a family environment. United has a strong community awareness and sets out to support the community in anyway possible.
cons: There are people in our 'family' that don't always know the whole story when they are always behind doors high up in the sky. They didn't suffer or sacrifice as much as we here on the ground did to keep this airline going. We work day in day out to keep money coming in and make sure every plane leaves with a good ROI. However some 'people' think that they are the most important in this company. Talk to everyone not just flight crew. Everyone has something to do with what this airline makes the best in class. As every family has it's issues (so do I sometimes) we need to get pass that. Let's keep the issues in the family and get this great airline going again stronger and better.

pros: Great peer support and technical skill at the operational level.  Experienced workforce and recognized industry leader in progressive safety program, the typical United front line employee has a lot to offer the customer, fellow employees and ultimately the company's ultimate success, if only they were given the opportunity.
cons: A legacy of  upper management that has routinely scored in the bottom rungs of the fortune 500 has poisoned the work force in terms of any possibility of trust or success in the near term.   Morale and performance have steadily declined since the failed ESOP, and a walk around the Willis tower (the new headquarters, which has drawn intense employee criticism because of commuting costs) reveals an expansive and expensive building complex surrounding a deflated work force.

review_title: Not like it used to be
pros: Company has great vision of what it wants to be among the airline industry and it tries to give its employees a wealth of training and provide salaries to be equal to the industry. New employees feel as if they are part of a team and work to achieve #1 Airline.
cons: When the merger happened, it should have been a complete merger. Let one airline take over the other. Not a "Merger of Equals". You have subCO, subUA and New United employees. Employees who worked for Continental thought we had a pretty good product and didn't see the need for a merger.  Years of the merger process and still not a Single Operating Carrier. Too many employees are disheartened that the company cannot go forward because of multi-systems not becoming ONE.

pros: I'm halfway through a 12-week internship, and it has been one of the most positive employment experiences of my life.  Everyone has been very helpful in bringing me up to speed and teaching me the things I need to know for success.  There's a very collaborative atmosphere, and I have had no problems reaching out to people in multiple departments who are willing to share their time.  Pay is very generous for a student internship, and of course flight benefits are something that few employers can offer.  Expectations are made very clear, and I have been given more than ample support in reaching my goals.  They are also very respectful of employee needs and concerns from everything I've seen.
cons: There are the same organizational issues with any large corporation -- IT delays and such. It seems at times that intern work assignments are not as well planned as I would hope, which has led to occasional down time.

job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros:
United Airlines has excellent travel benefits for employees, parents and dependents. It is standby
travel in any class of service and it is easy for employees to check the flight loads. Employees can sit in first class on an international flight and they pay a small fee. United has very good employees and it is really easy to make friends there. The work schedule is flexible.
cons:
The salaries are very low and the airline industry is unstable. United is reducing their workforce and
have many layoffs now.  The oil prices are so high now causing the airlines to ground more planes and reduce their staff, so it is not a good time to work in the airline industry.  The employee morale is low and there is a lot of tension between management and the employees. There are not many opportunities for promotions.

pros: Its an excellent company with promising current and future success with some improvement.
cons: United Airlines should upgrade the safety and security of all its workplaces,hubs.Security at chelsea should be upgraded,because in today's world companies like United have the potential to maintain secured work environment and practice in order to provide collective safety to its employees,customers and the general public as well as that of United chelsea so that it could be in a better position to counter balance the safety threats of our times by so doing it shall deliver safe,secured and pleasant service to all its customers while providing safer work environment to its employees.

review_title: Great benefits if you love traveling
pros:
The company just went through a big reorg and the current economic conditions are favorables for the airline industry. 
Employees morale seems to have improved for the first time since the merge with Continental. 
There's a new strategic vision and a new renovated organizational structure more aligned with the technology demands of the sector--e.g: investment in machine learning, getting in the cloud, become more agile.
cons:
Like in many large and old companies, the org structure is very hierarchical with many mid-level layers and incompetent leadership, with redundancy on job responsibilities, and a lot of resistance to change. The company wants to become agile but it's just a false illusion. 
Clear favoritism and workplace politics which cause managers and senior leaders to focus more on having meeting and building presentations than actually doing real work and deliver. 
Highly dependent on external vendors to do the work, which most of the times is bad quality and expensive.
Conflicts of interests when some senior leaders have stock or are on the board of some of the firms United hires to work on. 
Inflated job titles is very common. 
No culture (at least in Management).

review_title: Management - improve the airline instead of merging it!  If you value us we will be glad to work at it.
job_title: Engineering Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: Some people (including myself) have the "bug" to work in aviation. I enjoy the aircraft and the industry and I enjoyed my first twenty years with United.  It is an interesting and challenging career.
cons: Since exiting bankruptcy the engineering groups (considered management) have lost;  50% of our pension, 20% of our  base salary, one week of vacation, two holidays and any sense of job security.  The responce from our VP was "We can't make you happy",  He gave a nice RA-RA speech then left the company  two weeks latter, his repacement was latter laid off, and the division downgraded to a department.  It has gone down hill morale wise in the last three years.  The managers are so much under the gun for performance that there is little value, respect or appreciation shown to the rank and file, just threats of more layoffs.

review_title: Toronto Station-Outsourced by Airport Terminal Services (ATS)
pros: Flexible hours, 40 hours a week
cons: Not being employed under United Airlines' payroll really is so depressing and doesn't motivate employees to do their jobs with enthusiasm.  Most agents don't care whether work is done the right/proper way due to lack of incentives, proper training on each station, and lack of management assistance and awareness in dealing with so many issues. Favoritism is the name of the game. After working 9 months under ATS, even working full time we don't have benefits, promised raise after 6 months was not honored, agents work hard for nothing but the minimum wage. We all feel being taken advantaged of the whole situation.

review_title: Loved my career; disappointed with new structure from merger.
pros: Travel, Insurance, 401K, friendships developed.
cons:
Body clock is off from traveling with n different time zones.
Management seemed to be encouraged to assume that you were suspect if any incident occurred. 
It seemed there was a divide between original United and the flight attendants from Continental when the merger went through.
Continental's management took over and their clientele was geared more towards family travelers, vacationers. Where as United's core flyers were business accounts/travelers. I felt that the new management didn't take this factor into consideration and lost a number of the original United's business flyers accounts. The new management was very defensive, not open to hear other views and stuck in their ways of doing things. 
***Please keep in mind that there is a new CEO in place, since I left a couple of years ago, so things may have changed.*****

pros: United has come a LONG way since the merger in 2010.  I have found that the leadership team in my division (Airport Operations) is open, honest, and is very welcoming.  This is my third time coming back to United voluntarily.  The work attire is extremely casual, as management wants you to feel comfortable while working.  There are great networking and volunteer activities throughout the company.   Team members are respected and given latitude when necessary to make critical decisions.
cons: No tuition reimbursement exists at United today.  Also, the options for health care coverage are somewhat limited.  The adoption assistance program does not pay out much, unlike other companies (it is $2K per child).  Also, the company does not offer any gym facilities at their main Corporate Service Center - Willis Tower.  United has the "United 100" program for employee recognition, however it should implement small little rewards.  It'd be nice if you can nominate your coworker and give them a $25, $50, or $75 gift card.

pros: The package benefits and flying for free
cons:
They DO and WILL NOT train you. I had to ask supervisors who then referred me to leads who were not only incompetent but would literally yell at you for asking them questions

You have to ask employees to train you at a station even though you have worked here for only a week in addition to training others who have been present for a day.

Supervisors don't take you seriously. Only when the FDA is present then suddenly everyone has to have dry ice on the trays.

They WILL play favorites

job_title: Customer Service Agent in Houston, TX
pros: Regained seniority, flight benefits, health insurance , flexible work schedule, now friendly work environment, better pay, opportunity to continue my career and grow by working for the company that I love.
cons: Former leadership inflexible, everything was always no, no opportunity to grow or advance career, leadership very indecisive and unable or unwilling to help or take a decision in order to help employees. Very low pay. Leadership were quick to blame employees that were result of their poor decisions. Poor or no employee recognition for outstanding job.

job_title: Flight Attendant in San Francisco, CA
pros: After a few years, there is a lot of time off flexibility as long as you are in the right base. Free standby travel. There is no manager breathing down your back. It is the perfect job for anyone who has a side hustle.
cons: Straight reserve system. If you are stuck in a base that is very senior, you can be on call 24 hours a day up to 6 days straight. Its not so bad when they aren't using you so much but some times you can get used everyday for the six days up to 14 hours a day.  Its rare that that happens but it is a possibility.

review_title: Management shows little to no respect for flight attendants
pros: Travel benefits were a plus in the event you were actually able to get on. Most layover hotels were quite nice. Health insurance was very good if you had time to use it. Many great coworkers but many more extremely bitter.
cons: Long-time employees were extremely disgruntled and constantly complaining about "the company" and about working conditions which made for a very uncomfortable working atmosphere. Union dues were very high but there didn't seem to be anything positive gained from having a union. The only time I saw the effect of the union was when employees who repeatedly broke company rules (failing drug tests, etc) were protected from discipline or from losing their jobs.

review_title: Frustration and happiness all at the same company
job_title: Customer Service Representative in Washington, DC
pros:
Working for the world's largest airline with a massive route structure/franchise provides extraordinary opportunities for both professional and personal growth. Professional because you can move up--one recent CEO (Goodwin) started as a staff accountant, and I personally know many other upper level senior managers and executive (1 VP and several sub-VPs) who have risen through the ranks to very high level positions. Personal because you have amazing travel opportunities, and many jobs are available in multiple locations, especially airport and inflight operations and airport and inflight management.

Also . . . airline culture is what keeps people together; most people love aviation and travel. Aside from business tension, the culture is great! Many people at all levels, love their jobs, because they love airplanes and they love travel.
cons: Internal hires/promotions always pay less than "off the street" new hires from elsewhere. Labor and management seem constantly at odds, and pay is always low for non-management; only marginal to average for lower to mid-level management. Of course, upper level management does well.

job_title: Ramp Service Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: At United we all work as a team, great co-workers while some can be not so great. Great benefits especially travel to many destinations. We have co-workers who go above and beyond to help others since the new CEO and President came in. Can be a great company to work with when you have great management.
cons: Salary is okay when you first start, but after a few years Union contract hourly pay goes up. Management at the station does not care much about employees and operation, please understand to operate one of the world's largest airline at a Hub, we need strict and better managing to engage in smooth, stress-free, and happy employees.

job_title: Flight Attendant in San Francisco, CA
pros:
• Some of your coworkers are fun to be around & make you look forward to going to work.
• The travel benefits (if you manage to get on the packed planes) are good.
• Travelling the world as your job.
cons:
• Continental management has poisoned original United management's way of thinking.
• H.R. couldn't care less about you, the employee.
• While technically a "pro", medical & dental are more expensive & cover less than ever before. 
• Some employees (flight attendants in particular) are VERY cliquish & can be those "bad apples" you hear about.
• The pay is terrible & in no way matches what they post as paying (unless you're very senior & work specific positions).
• The odd & sometimes long hours can be tough on your body.  (Look up 'Non 24')
• It's hard to eat healthy when your only food options are airplane food, or airport food.
• You aren't a member of a "family" anymore. You're a number. And that's it.
• There's no growth as a flight attendant other than gaining seniority (unless you transfer to a management position).

review_title: United Airlines is a great company to learn all aspects of avaition and the workings of a global corporation.
pros:
- Untold opportunity for a dedicated, driven individual
- Microcosim of the transport and aviation industry covering all aspects of the corporate world
- Global experience and exposure for those who desire it
- Strong benefits, matching 401K and of course, flight benefits
- Great employees
- Diversity, challenge, opportunity for those willing to put in the work
- Great opportunities to grow your skill-set and expand into a variety of disciplines
- Industry leader
- Global
- Globally recognized brand image
cons:
- Corporate mentality at times hinders forward thinking growth
- Still trying to establish their identify post-merger
- Can be bureaucratic and slow to respond to continuous improvement
- Need to live "best of the best" and avoid decisions based on "Continental way" or "United way"
- Truly become a single carrier focused on the customer and employee engagement

review_title: Corporate real estate, planning and development
pros: Benefits, ability to travel for work
cons: Must be located at a Hub or CSC to hold a position. Low project management salerys to include poor annual salary increases( 1.5-2% average). In addition, as employees have commented on the poor salaries leadership feels that a position is only worth so much so hard work and dedication has no value.  Department used to be known for hiring construction professionals, now with current leadership you don't have to have any professional construction knowledge to work in this department. Everything is process and document management which takes away time to actually manage the construction project- No longer construction oriented. Lack of opportunities for growth for project managers.

review_title: Years after merger there are still issues
pros: The  people I work with have a lot of knowledge that I rely on because I don't always get information from the company I need.  The benefits - 401(k), health, travel, etc are great.
cons:
EZR/Shares isn't as good as FastRes/Apollo. There are many functions in FastRes that would make our jobs so much easier to assist the customer, but sub CO decided to go with the system they knew when it was time to pick one or the other to use for the the merged company. 
Supervisors are not given any flexibility when working with employees. Medical issues are not considered if there the time going to the bathroom is "too high".
Resources are often vague or out of date. We often hear in training "this is supposed to be how it will work" or "that part hasn't been worked out yet".

pros: Being a larger global presence there are better opportunities for international flying if that's what's important to you.  Bases throughout US, and several in Europe and Asia.
cons: The company is so horribly divided since the merger 5 YEARS ago!  It's simply unacceptable to take 5 years to fully merge everyone.  Sadly it's corporate keeping the division going even in so much that they continue to hire FAs on either "Sub-CO or Sub-UA" sides.  The bottom line is it affects the customers and they are the key component of success for the company.  Along with poor leadership I seriously don't see how this company will sustain itself for 10 more years.  The employees are miserable, the customers don't feel appreciated and the leadership isn't leading.

pros: The organization is working very hard to make a better experience for customers and employees.   Though the work can be difficult, employees are quite positive and willling to go the extra mile to deliver on a project.  It is great that business travel is supported as it gives employees the chance to meet other team members and understand more about locations they support.  The leadership is very focused on the customer facing employees and really wants the new exciting culture to take hold.
cons: One serious national incedent or economic decline has a devastating impact on the airline industry.  This creates a need for cost efficiencies that can go too far.  Finance should focus on finance, technology should focus on tech and HR should focus on HR - not get involved in each others business and make things difficult.

review_title: A promising company in a fascinating industry
pros:
- Tons to learn in a complex, highly-competitive industry
- Career mobility is top priority and encouraged
- A great time to be a part of creating the new United after merging with Continental
- Lots of smart, hard-working, and down-to-earth people
cons:
- Still trying to shake off latent bureaucracy and improve inefficient processes
- Culture in flux after merger, and not clearly defined
- Unions and fuel prices make consistent profitability extremely difficult
- Need to standardize how good personal performance is rewarded and poor performance is corrected

review_title: Overall a good place to work if you negotiated good package while joining.
job_title: Lead Programmer Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: After recent IT restructuring, its now a good place to work. The obvious benefit of working in Airline is the space available travel and I am sure there are lot of people who are working only for that. Salaries are slightly less compare to market but if you use some traveling benefit, it compensate for that.
cons: Just like any other travel industry, United Airline is very sensitive to Overall Economy. Till last year back, atleast in IT, there were constant hiring and firing. As soon there is improvement in economy, they will hire people and if the oil goes up or on slight market condition, they will dump you. Overall its better to be in technical position from a job security point of view

review_title: United Airlines Senior Management does not know how to treat their employees!
pros: If you want to make a "somewhat" reasonable wage for doing absolutley nothing, this is the place for you.  There is no accountability for anything.  No one is held accountable, even though everyone there talks the talk, they don't walk the walk.  They say they want accountability, but have no clue on how to achieve it.  The lack of developement is very previlent.
cons: There is no accountability.  The wages are still dated from the 1990's.  Wages for the people who have been there for 20 years plus and have been there to help the company get through a bankruptcy, are pathetic.  The people are being told to change,,,,,, but have no clue how to.  There is no guidence.

review_title: UAL; How to run a good company into the ground.
pros:
UAL may merge with Continental.  This is the only reason I can see for working at United (and it's admittedly a stretch).
If a merger takes place, Continental management would likely run the combined airline in which case you'd be working for management who 1) has the ability to manage and 2) has an interest other than lining their pockets.
Without a merger with Continental there is no reason to go with UAL.   
Frontline employees are another plus at United although it's hard to tell how long that will last under management's current campaign of harassment.  With the pressure frontline employees are under, it's only a matter of time before they start to crumble.
cons: The biggest downside is the CEO (Glenn Tilton).  He's demonstrated over and over again his inability to run an airline.   He is quite good at lining his pockets.  --He's the world's highest paid airline CEO but runs one of the least profitable companies.  Go figure.  Might have something to do with him appointing more than a few people to the board of directors.  God help UAL under his reign.  --And God help the next company he "manages."

job_title: Senior Manager Flight Operations in Chicago, IL
pros: They are trying to rectify years of bad luck and mismanagement.
cons: There is really no reason to be middle management at United. Variable compensation is tied to items nowhere in our direct control and metrics that don’t have targets that can be communicated to us except generally. A level 4-3 manager has no plan or program, incentive or perk that is set aside alone for the burden of leadership. And while that may sound selfish, for the level of change that has been pushed to all workgroups, and the positional authority we share with our peers across industry, we aren’t even allowed to book business class regularly (capacity controls have been put in place on “pretty much all flights”) or use any of the perks we purchase through our card programs, for business travel.

job_title: Network Planning Intern in Chicago, IL
pros: Talented, passionate and encouraging co-workers.  I look forward to being with my team every day and learning something new.  They really invest in me to help me grow by taking the time to explain things to me and giving me meaningful challenging work. I've learned more than just my department and had a great time getting to meet Senior VPs as well as the CEO.  We work in the Willis tower and have the opportunity to network with people throughout the corporation.  The flight benefits are an additional excellent benefit of working for the airline.
cons: Living in Chicago is really expensive.  The pay is comparable but the stipend for living is well below the cost of living and the housing suggestions that were sent to us.  They also keep a very lean work force so entry-level full time positions can be hard to come by.

review_title: It may be a bumpy ride.  Fasten your seatbelts.
pros: Flight benefits are what keeps most people.  The team I worked with were outstanding.  The network of other admins was also an outstanding resource.  But the changeover in management caused problems.  Printing policies and info on the internet was also valuable.
cons: Inconsistency on leadership.  Had to fight to get good resources and training although the job itself was not difficult.  In efforts to save costs, would not always staff adequately enough.  Management playing favorites caused dissention and made having a union shop absolutely necessary for fair treatment.  Also, their efforts to self-audit on accounting meant they really did not follow patterns that would allow anyone to actually know good profit and loss figures.  It was an accountants nightmare or dream depending on how you looked at it.

pros: Flight benefits aren't bad since you always have the jumpseat option.  Most coworkers were very nice to work with especially the ramp guys and pilots.  Good health benefits.  Mechanics do maintain the aircraft very well.  Great job if you love traveling.  A/B rotation isn't bad.  Crew desk takes a little getting use to but overall are good people with work with.  Lots of time off.
cons: Flight benefits can be challenging at times, spent 2 days in Tampa trying to get on a flight out of there.  A lot of very nice flight attendants to work with and some appear detached from life.  Supervisors try using scare tactics and target you when they don't work.  Salary is ridiculously too low.  Management will believe passengers before believing a flight attendant.  Layovers in nice places are much shorter nowadays.  Must be very cautious about what you say around other flight attendants who are very sneaky.  Being a Purser truly was a mistake.

review_title: Employees need to see a plan, the potential is here but the leadership is not.
job_title: Airplane Pilot Or Copilot in San Francisco, CA
pros:
The possibility of paycheck continuity.  
Actually, there are many very good people working within this company but they have been beaten down for so long that it is hard to find much optimism. In reading the reviews, I notice that the only positive ones come from those working in the office. Those who are actually working in or around the airplanes and attempting to keep the operation side functioning have a different perspective.
cons: Senior management has no plan. An Airline has to be dynamic and look for areas to solidify routes and carefully expand. Shrinking to profitability is a strategy for failure. Glen Tilton and his crew have shrunken staffing (except in the executive ranks) to a point where the airline does not function well. To the degree that it does function, it is only due to the continued dedication of the employees in the face of failed management policies.

review_title: I did not believe that our own CEO does not fly in our airplanes, but I rarely keep track of his personal travel.
pros: I am employeed and for that, I'm blessed.  Working here has allowed me the oppotunity of reaching areas in this world not many will ever acheive.
cons: I wish for better work tools, a more friendly work environment and a return to trust.  Until then, I hold my breath for impending doom as I have watched - too many to count  -  employees being furloughed.  My main work computer is still running Windows 95 and I see more BLUE screen than anything else.

pros: Pay was...OK, New Jets.  Gave me my start in Aviation
cons: I quit shortly before the merger in 2010 Coworkers referring to themselves as Wickins  seemed to hate Christians.   The occult seemed to have taken over the company shortly before the merger with United.    Also the CEO at the time of the merger was a big supporter of Planned Parenthood.. The union representing the mechanics (Teamsters) always seems to be trying to get control of the pension fund.  The stock purchase program seemed fixed too as the price of the stock usually seemed to drop below the minimum purchase price around the yearly purchase date then rise back up shortly afterword.  They also consessioned away the overtime pay that you'd get for extra hours on trade days worked.   Starting in 1995 The company subleased away its Denver hub (brand new DIA terminal and hanger) to Frontier Airlines and later closed its LAX Maintenance Base shanghighing those mechanics into IAH or EWR or GSO which It closed later.   Then after 9/11 it closed more smaller maintenance stations for cost cutting but didn't reopen instead its feeder airline took some of them over.

review_title: Fair, Balanced, with Room for Improvement
pros: Innovative work in the marketing/e-commerce department.  Good opportunity to gain exposure to interactive marketing projects focused on B2C product delivery, driving revenue via conversion of consumer transactions, and brainstorming and implementing creative strategies to significantly impact the customer experience and satisfaction (when not constrained by administrative budget issues).
cons: The company has been impacted by too many volatile industry variables, such as fuel costs, and has a recent trending towards frequent labor shifts (i.e., layoffs/furloughs, bankruptcy, salary paycuts, reduction-in-force/cost saving initiatives, etc.).  Additionally, the travel industry is very fossilized, which results in a reliance on traditional business practices and methodologies, many of which are impractical in a constantly evolving industry-specific sector.  Professional growth and career advancement can become stagnant and/or be omitted as a result of frequent cost-cutting and labor dislocation.

job_title: Flight Officer in San Francisco, CA
pros: A legacy US carrier that has morphed over the years from providing a quality luxury experience to a commodity environment to compete with the competition.  The Company is still in the consternation of the merger with Continental and has yet to define its own culture.  Its a job in today's worrisome labor market and does provide some modest benefits.   As with most things in life...the idea of working for an airline and the reality are quite different.
cons: The merger with Continental still provides a lot of unanswered questions and will probable take another 3-5 years to identify the questions much less provide appropriate answers.  Benefits such as pass travel can be useful, but are highly overrated by the general public.

review_title: it could be a great company
job_title: Flight Officer in San Francisco, CA
pros: flying airplanes, my great fellow employees, a great company with a great bit of history and the potential to do great things and have a bright future. I could be very proud again to fly for United Airlines if this company had a real leader and visionary at the helm.
cons:
it used to be a real career, but as long as things don't change drastically for the better, it's only a job. it's very sad for me to make such a statement,very sad.
I used to be so very proud to be a United Pilot, but the last seven or so years of being treated like the enemy, being disregarded and not valued for any efforts, that just about did it.
I fly my plane with top performance and motivation,  that's what aviators do. For the company: they get job performance, not career performance. I used to promote United out of pride, now I only do it if you pay me for it... until you give me a reason to be proud again to fly for United.

review_title: United Airlines - The Ups and Downs of the Airline Industry
pros: UA has always been pretty good at promoting from within the company.  It's reasonable to expect that many middle and upper-level managers have been promoted from within the company rather than having been hired from the outside.  The airline industry is exciting and always changing, and the people who work here are loyal and want to see the company succeed.
cons: The pay is not equitable with similar work outside of the company.  UA is not a place that provides an incredible amount of job security.  And, like any big corporation, office politics often decides who gets the peachy assignments and promotions.

review_title: United has provided well for me
pros: I have fantastic benefits that most employers no longer offer. I have medical and dental insurance. I get bonuses. I am a full time employee when most employers only hire part time to avoid giving benefits. I can purchase supplemental insurance which will pay me in the event of unforeseen medical absences from work. My schedule is so unbelievably flexible. I don't take work home with me. I work with many interesting people that help make my job even more fun.
cons: It is a physical job with lots of heavy lifting. Passengers have a lot of unrealistic expectations of you and often take their frustrations out on you.

review_title: THIS COMPANY IS THE ABSOLUTE WORST TO WORK FOR AS A FLIGHT ATTENDANT.
pros: Medical benefits; free flying benefits--that is if there is an available seat.
cons: No respect at all from management; flight attendants are treated like children by management , for example, we are given "points" for taking sick days and then have our hands slapped after accumulating a certain number of points.  We are paid $1.80 per hour for the time we are working, but not actually in the air.   Our new hires make less than $18,000 per year, but the Company asked that they do not stand in line for food stamps while in uniform!   Our CEO, Glenn Tilton, is an idiot--he recently hedged on oil and, of course, the price of oil then went down.  He took a $35 million bonus, after reducing flight attendants' salaries and taking their pension plans away.  Mr. Tilton has said that being a flight attendant should not be a career. He moved management offices to downtown Chicago at the cost of who knows how much, while we already own property/offices in Elk Grove Village.   I could go on and on and on..., but need I say more???

review_title: Survived despite the best efforts of DEN management to run the station into the ground.
pros: healthcare, wage, pension, and travel benefits, schedule flexibility, the variety and number of coworkers, working outdoors in beautiful Colorado weather
cons: An ongoing regime of uncommunicative, disinterested, Machiavellian, and apathetic managers - anyone who should know what the future of the Denver hub is either doesn't know or isn't saying.  Over 50% of  peers in Ramp Service  job classification are part time while peers in other hubs with less seniority are full time - this is contactually allowed but we have never been given the courtesy of an explanation for the business reason for this arrangement.  Local management refuses to create additional money making opportunities for UAL at Denver hub - limited ground service and de/anti icing for United Express and Star Alliance carriers.  A steady march towards line station status.

review_title: A poorly run organization and impersonal atmosphere.
pros: Occasional incentive bonuses, meals provided in cafeteria.
cons: A constant race against time catering aircraft, often larger or medium size aircraft that used to use 2 people you now have to do by yourself under tough time constraints, will always be working nights, weekends, holidays your first few years with little seniority, rigid full time schedules have little or no flexibility, therefore difficult to have a life outside of work, let alone use your travel benefits- flights often oversold with long standby lists, making non-reving even more difficult, poor communication from management, always kept in the dark about schedule changes and other important information until the very last minute, facility is often short on needed catering equipment(carts, ice bins, coffee pots, radios, etc.) during busy times.

review_title: In 23+ yrs at UAL, I have seen the downward spiral of a leader in the industry as it raced to the bottom.
pros: My fellow employees, we have banded together in misery in hopes of improving our working conditions. the work we do is really to make the best of a bad and uncaring situation for our customers in the attempt to improve our self image against a managment team bent only on their own greed.
cons: The lack of leadership or their desire to blame or make the employee the scapegoat of their inability to run a company in the 21st century.  the time is now to adopt the practices of the new age of employee relations and drop the 19th century practice of command and control. if United is to succeed it needs to take a serious look at and accept a new model of employee involment in the company.

review_title: Culture of dignity and respect, open and honest communication. Is any current employee not laughing?
pros: Decent pay and vacation. Most other benefits such as pension have been lost.
cons: Since the merger, Continental has replaced most management with their people. Since then we have had every process go their way right or wrong. Absolutely no communication. The new culture is one of "I don't want to hear it". Very intimidating command and control environment. Little by little our maintenance jobs are moving to Houston and Chicago. They are reducing numbers in CA by making life miserable for the employees who have served the company for decades. This is culturally ill company that is just asking for trouble by choosing lax quality controls and standards. Being at work is less cheerful than a morgue. I personally do not know 1 person who enjoys their job. This situation here is very similar to what Continental did to Eastern. Unfortunately Continental is still the same rotten employer it was back then.

review_title: Depends on your station & who is not outsourced yet.
pros:
Unlimited flying benefits
Somewhat flexible schedule
cons:
Unlimited flying benefits only if you are flying to a location nobody wants to go to--good luck getting on a small jet.  Just buy airfare on another airline & get there & enjoy your vacation.
United going through 45 stations & outsourcing ramp and agents.
Too many ERJ Jets--what consumer wants to fly on them?  No business person wants these.

pros: Great induction to the company. The employee package was good at the time I worked there in 1999-2000 with good prospects. You have the chance to swap and change shifts with other workers to add days on to your vacation you book. A friendly company and HR door was always open to any issues I had or just want to talk to someone if it was work related or personal life related. The company gave us a free flight during the introduction period to experience the service of the company which I thought was a nice gesture. Management was always approachable from Crew chiefs, Ramp service directors and People services department. (HR)
cons: Sometimes during the summer it would get very hectic up there at terminal 3 but I never saw it as a problem. Just have to remain focussed and calm. Pressure is probably not for everyone but I think it is the way you handle it. And with this company, the door is always open to talk about any issues you have.

review_title: United chelsa catering a sweat shop environment
pros: Flying cheap, buddy passes for family and friends no longer worth it . Cost is usually the cost of 2 or more weekend advanced  tickets . Charged for bags
cons:
Any position in United Catering division is not worth it .. Super dysfunctional mgmt
From top Blair down to the supervisors .. Total disreguard for All nj state labor laws, no union , turn over ratio is extremely high..  Very racist divsion. No raises unless minimum wage increases..

review_title: UNITED USED TO BE THE BEST AIRLINE!! NOW IT'S ONE OF THE WORST!!!
pros: The flexibility, days off, vacation time, better trips with seniority, international layovers, free or discounted unlimited travel
cons: pay cuts,  loss of pensions, medical insurance not as good as it used to be,  if youre junior, awful domestic flying, short layovers out by airport, bad moral with fellow employees, some of my worst flights have been working with mean, bitchy flight attendants, lots of attitude

pros: Colleagues are the finest to work with, and made flights flow with ease. I met passengers with fields of interest that I learned from every flight in my 24.5 years
cons: I was fired 1 month before full retirement. I was denied FMLA even though a Cat scan, MRIs, orthopedic surgeon and GP verified a medical condition. United Medical said not enough info. Metlife found enough info for my LTD, and I needed no attorney to convince them. My supervisor notified me on Monday of  a hearing on Tues that took two flights to attend and I couldn't in short notice, so in the hearing I made she said twice that I missed a meeting. All notices came via DBS, they're exempt from mail fraud. My termination letter came USPS.

job_title: Flight Attendant in Los Angeles, CA
pros: The pros for becoming a flight attendant would still be flexibility regarding one's schedule and hours worked, and a great pass travel package.
cons: The perks are quickly disappearing. Layovers are becoming shorter, and in airport hotels rather than nice downtown locations. The unions are weak, if not corrupt. Most f/a's have stopped even trying to use travel privileges, as the flights are always full.  Your fellow employees can be wonderful, but that is the exception. There is much bitterness, laziness, sometimes utter hostility from the gate agents, management, and especially passengers. Be prepared to be utterly unappreciated and to have to fight for respect.

review_title: Pilots, start saving your money.  We will strike UAL in 2010!
job_title: Airplane Pilot Or Copilot in Dulles, VA
pros: There are people who are trying to make a go of this once good company.  I think they are simply wasting there efforts and energy on a dying entity.  The slave traders and robber barons called united management will get their blood money from the employees as long as they are ready to keep giving more these vampires. Someone or some group is going to have to strike this company to get there attention.  Nothing else is going to bear fruit except to shut it down.  Anyone who believes otherwise is simple delusional.  There are no got reasons to work for ual except for not having any other prospects.  Ual really sucks!!!!!!!
cons: Pay, benefits, lost pensions, broke airplanes, no brand, treat passangers horribly, try to make pilots take mainteneace questionalbe aircraft.  Glenn Tilton is the most incapable airline CEO since Frank lorenzo, His mangement teams could not find employment at a Taco Bell.  Someone please tell me one thing they have done in the last 5 years besides take from the employees.

review_title: Don't come to work here unless you just can't get hired anywhere else to gain the experience.
pros: You can travel if you are single and have the time. It is space available travel so if there are no seats left after the normal passengers are boarded, you will wait until the next flight. You can usually get out the same day if you are alone, but if you have more than one, than you could be there for days i.e. Hawaii- space available passengers have been stuck for days trying to get out of Hawaii. Not good if you have to be at work the next day.
cons: The worst moral I have ever experienced at any company. Our CEO is on the record for saying "moral is not his problem". They treat the employees with the attitude that "your lucky to just have a job".  The upside is that if we get new management that wants to run an airline like Southwest management, we would be the #1 major airline in the country. Pay is far below competitors.

pros: Having the chance to see parts of the world that I normally wouldn't.
cons:
The morale is low. I can tell that many of us are down trodden. The merger is taking incredibly long, and I don't see any major changes happening soon. There's so much division between what the Continental flight attendants want, and what the United flight attendants want. I don't know who thought this merger would be a good idea, but it's not going smoothly. 
The schedulers don't work with the flight attendants. It's almost like they're on a power trip. Although we are unionized, sometimes it seems pointless. The schedulers don't know the contract and sometimes will do whatever they want to us and then tell us to file a grievance with the union. I know we're supposed to be flexible with our schedules, but it's starting to be ridiculous. I'm starting to look into other airlines.

pros: Being a flight attendant is a wonderful job once you have some seniority, Reserve is not a cake walk and in order for you to be successful, you must be ready for the challenges it presents. Some realistic challenge include but are not limited to: six weeks of unpaid training, relocating to some of the most expensive cities in the country, and reserve- having no control over you schedule.
cons: In order to be successful you MUST live in the city where you are based. I do not understand why flight attendants commute- especially new flight attendants. Not only are new flight attendants  The company does not encourage it, What other job do you not have to live where you work?? If you are going into this with the hopes to commute, reconsider.

review_title: Benefits are fantastic until you really need them
job_title: International Flight Attendant in Honolulu, HI
pros: Benefits are the best,  however if you hurt yourself at work United punishes you by slowly removing access to these benefits by design.
cons: After going on workman's comp from an injury sustained at work on the job  my benefits were taken away from me one by one and each supplemental policy i purchased through United or the flight attendant union or United subsiderary was denied because they said I sent my payment in late. For  each one they said the same thing and it was a total lie. They changed my employee records to make it seem that I was not being compliant with their requests, when I was. Along with many other false statements and defamatory comments that were placed in my work history file.;

review_title: This is UA Hell, not UAL
pros: It is one of the few places where a person will be paid to learn.  There are some very good people working at this company.  Unfortunately, they have been screwed over many times during there tenure at UAL that they now really don't care.  If you can ever get on a flight, the flight benefits can be wonderful.  Flying first class internationally can be a real treat.  I have seen some of the best places in the world flying on United.
cons: You are working for a dead company.  People are beat down, management is hording the carrots and giving only the stick to the employees.  It is not a secret that Tilton wants to sell the company, so an employee never knows how much job security he or she has.  You have to work alot of nights and alot of weekends until you get enough seniority to bid a shift that doesn't require it.  It can take a toll on family life and a persons heath.

review_title: Merger Pains, but Truly Turning the Corner!
pros:
Decent pay, but the benefits are excellent!
Health, 401k, bonus, profit sharing, flight benefits
Things are changing so the opportunity for advancement is always open
Lots of focus on employee recognition
A very strong focus on working together and creating a positive work environment
Opportunity to work with an airline that is looking towards the future of how to sustain a profit instead of the boom-bust cycle of the past
cons:
Some of the internal processes make no sense (but they are trying to improve)
Some upper management is still sour about the past
Some of the employees refuse to accept the merger (we are merged, get over it...it isn't going to change)
Flying stand by can be challenging due to the size of the company and all of the employees wanting to travel

job_title: Administrative Assistant in San Francisco, CA
pros:
I've only been here less than a month, but already feel part of the United family. This is not a feeling I got with some of the other jobs I've had elsewhere.
People are very warm and welcoming, there's no resentment of new hires, and they do all they can to help the newbies find their feet.
My managers are very encouraging and allow me to arrange my work environment and work flow in a way that's comfortable and efficient for me, so that I get a sense of actually "owning" my work.
There's no micromanagement in my department, which makes the work more pleasant and interesting for self-starters like me.
Work-life balance is cool, there's no call to be working overtime and on days off, unlike in some other jobs.
And the benefits are great, particularly the pass travel, though I haven't tried it yet.
I love it here, and am looking to stay for the rest of my career.
cons: The pay should be more responsive to the cost of living in our area.

review_title: Lack of fairness and respect from a management that has no problem serving themselves.
pros: Employees are among the best in the industry.  The management refuses to harness the employee potential.  They insist on being the 'premier' airline of choice while expecting the employees to work with sub-standard pay, work rules and benefits.
cons: Lowest pay among the major airlines.  Employees are still woking with a bankruptcy contract long after the company exited bankruptcy and is now merging with Continental.  It is criminal the way management treats the employees at United.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Francisco, CA
pros: With new leadership in place, Oscar Munoz focus on customers and employee satisfaction is evident. By resolving customers concerns, introducing  better quality products and services, and investing in new technology United is transitioning to distinguish its brand as a distinguished and exclusive entity sought by premier travelers. Senior leadership is working diligently to streamline labor issues and create one company with one focus ahead.
cons:
There is still more work to do in terms of quality meals and products in the Economy cabin. The snacks, meals, utensils aren't as comparable as other Star Alliance members.
There's still more work to do in the area of employee recognition and the effective utilization of mid management and junior supervisors making more effort in employee engagement and promoting equal opportunities at all levels of the operation.

pros:
I love working here. These are some of the most passionate group of people I have ever met in my life.  I got furloughed once (unfortunately, but I understood) and honestly I was very much looking forward to coming back.  Very diverse workforce, respect for differences of all kinds, opportunity to make a difference in customer's experience. 

Lots of more changes coming up.  It's an exciting time to be at United.
cons: There is a lot of work.  We are ALWAYS burning the candle at both ends.  I have a very flexible supervisor but I know not all people have a flexible supervisor.  If you like to work hard and you are passionate about what you do, you're good.  If you are looking for "just a job" this might not be it.

review_title: Used to work for a great airline, then I worked here...same uniform!
pros:
Memories of past stellar professionalism and excellent values, not to mention integrity!
Memories of how it should be done...past pride in doing a truly great job with great people.
cons:
Words and not deeds, bare minimums and cost control trumps all.
Non collaborative management, more like slave drivers.
No real leadership.
Only "friendly" if you are agreeable with everything regardless of how crazy it is.
Aggressively antagonistic management at all levels. 
Not receptive to critique or constructive criticism aimed at providing the best product.
Non-collaborative, despite saying preaching that they are.
Oppressive working conditions.
Hard to watch actual practices when you hear marketing misrepresentations of values.
Employees referred to as "coworkers" when really treated as liabilities, not assets.
Having to give customers dramatically decreased service and smile at the same time
Cheap, cheap, cheap.
Run by lawyers and not by operations professionals, as it should.

review_title: Satisfying but hard life for junior flight attendant
pros: Flight benefits are awesome. United flies everywhere, so a current employee and his/her partner, parents and kids can travel to many destinations in the world for free. Another great thing are the coworkers. We have always a smile for each other, and you rarely get to fly with the same people, so you get to know a lot of very nice flight attendants everyday. It also offers flexibility to your schedule
cons: When you are junior, the paycheck is very very sad. Once you get some seniority it improves. Junior flight attendants are usually on reserve all year around, which makes our personal lives very hard. It can also be a lonely job, since you end up spending a lot of time away from home, in crashpads or layovers, far away from your people.

pros:
- Addicting to work for an airline.
- Benefit of having the capability to go anywhere in the world at any time, for as many times as you wish.
- The company is large enough for you to be able to move across departments and work in new fields without having to start a new career with a new corporation. 
- Most employees are very passionate about the company.
cons:
- It is a big company and it takes it a while to "turn" when implementing new ideas, new policies new direction...etc.
- Some people tend to work in silos.
- Sometimes decisions are made without thoroughly researching the impact across the employee body.

pros:
From the moment I walked into United, I immediately felt supported by my direct manager and peers. Yes, the company operates at lightning speed, but I am surrounded by people who truly care about aviation, connecting people, and United. There is a culture of meritocracy and everyone can raise their hand at the table. My colleagues are people who are passionate about their job, which is not only refreshing but makes it easier to go into work when its still dark in the morning.  

There is PLENTY of opportunity to bring innovative forward, even in a large company like United. I could see myself growing my career here for the long run!
cons: Since the company is so big, there are different functions for each aspect of the business. It's difficult to figure out the process of approval and can slow down things that need to get done.

review_title: United Senior Management needs to get in touch with its employees.
job_title: Engineer in South San Francisco, CA
pros: It is close to my house.  Commute time is less that 15 min.
cons: Inconsistant job security, just when you think the company is stable, Senior management uses furloughs to fix money maters.  Senior Level Management are being compensated even though working level employees are being furloughed.  Change the structure of the business practices.  Employee reduction is the only answer.  Company is mgmt top heavy and they are not held accountable at the corporate level.  Cut more at the top.

review_title: If you want to work for an airline, find one other than United.
pros: You have travel benefits and your fellow employees are a pleasure to work with.  If you like to have contact with the customer in your job, then United provides lots of that.
cons: The pay and benefits are less than at other airlines and are getting worse.  Senior management is more highly compensated that their peers at other airlines and continue to take millions from the company.  The employees have had their wages and benefits decimated since the bankruptcy.  An airline is a service business, but UA treats its front line employees very poorly.  This results in less than satisfactory service to the customers.  There seems to be a personal resentment on the part of senior management toward the employees.

pros: I really like the company in general. The people are polite, but still laid back. They take an interest in me and my development. The flight benefits are also great- you may have to be a little creative to use them but I've been able to go everywhere I want to.
cons:
Like anywhere, your boss and the people in your department can make or break your experience. I don't really like the group I currently work for.

Taxes on the flight benefits- not really United's fault, but I wish they had explained it better. If your +1 on you flight benefits is not your spouse, you are going to be taxed on them using your flight benefits. Round trip between Chicago and Washington DC costs me $85 in taxes, so it can add up.

pros: Most employees are dedicated to doing their job in a professional manner.  On days when there are no issues, weather, ATC, aircraft damages, employee injuries, etc. the job is easy.  It's a good job for those who don't want a 9 to 5 or to be confined to a desk.
cons: The downside is that there is almost always some issue to resolve!  That's basically why you have a job as a supervisor.  The thing is the job gets very old and mundane because the problems are usually the same.  ATC, weather, etc.  The employee morale is also a big problem.  Morale is down among all work groups, pilots, mechanics, agents, flight attendants, supervisors, etc.  Senior management has done little to address the issues that began with a poor ESOP plan, 9/11 furloughs, pension termination, etc.

pros: Travel benefits are fantastic.  My family and I have seen a lot of the world because of United. I work with an equally fantastic group of people and look forward to other opportunities within the company in the coming years.  We see be in strong growth mode which is a good thing.
cons: United seems to be headed in the right direction and has focused on it's people.   Hopefully that continues in the future.  Difficult as a pass rider to get on flights these days so you just have to manage and get creative.   Would be nice if a slightly deeper discount is offered for employees to purchase tickets but no complaints with current program.

pros: The best part about working for an airline (other than the travel benefits) is that there is always room to grow. If you are burned out from flying there are office opportunities that you can compete for. If you feel you need more of a challenge while in flight, you can apply to be a service manager. You never feel "stuck" like you have to do the same thing for the rest of your life.
cons: Reserve sucks. It takes so much out of you. They really need to change the reserve system because straight reserve for years is not healthy at all!

job_title: Flight Attendant in New York, NY
pros: Great travel benefits, awesome healthcare, you get to travel the world for free when working and very cheap on your time off.  they are very matriarchal and LGBT friendly, and diverse.  Lots of friendly people.  Starting pay $30k per year up to almost $120k after 13 years.
cons: You're away from home a lot, you start out on reserve which keeps you on call for all but 12 days out of each month.  Commuting to work via the airline and our partner airlines is allowed but plan on relocating for the first six months you're on probation.

job_title: Supervisor, Airport Operations in Dulles, VA
pros: A great company with a wonderful worlwide route structure. Lots of opportunity to travel. The mid-level supervisory staff generally does a good job in taking care of the customer contact employees (some much more so than others!).
cons: Unfortunately, promotion is still based on who you know versus what you know and how well you do your job. As with any "administration transition", when new station management takes over, current management personnel are let go-often under very curious circumstances-in order to free up positions for former colleagues and friends of the new administration. The pay rate is lower for tenured management employees than it is for new hire management employees with less experience and seniority.

pros: Benefits package unavailable in any other industry, opportunities for much flexibility in work schedules. Parking is paid. If you like work with the public, this is the job for you.
cons: CBA covered employees have seniority that is the guiding work rule for scheduling purposes. Seniority drives your hours of work, your days off, your holidays worked or off and your vacation time off. No retirement package, no 401k match. Corporate focus is on making profit, not on delivering superior service.

review_title: Long progressions and unfair point system
pros: Benefits for the whole family, including flights, medical, dental, vision, 401k
cons: The point system for absent, tardy, and using your sick time. Yes even when you are sick and bring proof like a doctors statement. You still will get a point, I was given a point when I had to go give birth to my child. It's hard to transfer into another station or job position mainly because people won't retire.

job_title: Airline Pilot, Captain in Denver, CO
pros: Great pay and schedules. Competent first officers. Generally friendly co-workers. Not much management interference. Chief Pilots are generally supportive. If you like to fly jets, it's awesome!
cons: The job can be frustrating sometimes. Small things turn into big things and people get upset. Being a captain who treats people well always helps.  It's a big corporation so you will always feel somewhat insignificant. If you can live with it and just enjoy flying the jet, it's awesome.

pros: Coworkers, management, and executives are almost entirely great people who care about your career - for example when I told my previous department director that I was bored with the work in that department and wanted to go somewhere else in the company, he was extremely supportive and honestly wanted me to be happy. My current department is very flexible with time (having to leave early for an appointment etc). Free flight benefits are awesome. Under the new CEO, employees are generally excited to work here.
cons: Salary is a little lower compared to other industries (not surprising given the financial instability in the industry). While the official benefits are excellent, a lot of little perks from my previous company are missing (company paid outings, meals, etc).

pros: Fast paced and you learn a lot about working on the ramp.  The company emphasizes safety first.  Most workers are very dedicated to their jobs.  Same flying benefits as regular United employees.
cons: The wage is very low.  About $9/hr to start with gradual increase.  Currently at $12/hr after 2 years.  I took the job mainly for the flying benefits, and that is the only reason I haven't left.  Management and workers are mostly Hispanic so learn Spanish.  The workers love their work, because most of them don't realize how badly they are being treated.  Not sure why union is not moving on so many possible new recruits, but I can guess it's because of language and cultural barrier.

review_title: Neither an enjoyable or awful place to work, but improving.
pros: The CEO seems to have the employees and the customers needs in mind with his actions.  He is turning the company in a better direction that will improve the image with the public and employees.  The company is generally a good place to work for a larger corporation, although it will never be the enjoyable environment to work in that Continental Airlines was.   Lots of good people to work with at the middle and lower levels.
cons: The IT department in Houston does not have very good morale because of all the cuts, and a general dislike and distrust of the IT management in Chicago.

review_title: Regrettably awful schedules, horrible work environments, employees are fearful and trapped.
