job_title: Food Production Agent in Newark, NJ
pros: Free lights, (overpriced) health insurance.
cons: The management does not show any care or regard for the health and safety of the employees. When their work environment is a constant 35°, and they get sick, management literally does not care and replaces them with another human robot that easily replaces every other person there. Everyone is easily replaced and therefore management does not care about any person who works there. Your health becomes a reason you will regret working there and you will be stuck at a job that will kill your body and when you accumulate even one point by getting sick or being late even once, consider that the nail in the coffin forcing you to do the same job you hate by them forcing you to quit working for the company, or continue to be miserable doing the job that is killing you, which you loathe (like me) with zero way out of it besides resigning to work for any better airline, which would be any airline in the entire industry.

pros: Good flight benefits, when you can get on a plane.
cons: Job security is always an issue and stressful to ones life and home life.  Extremely dysfuntional pay scale system.  Most of the employees have placed their heart and soul in to this company only to have their face slapped for doing so.  Retirement package was taken away and benefits reduced.  Management is required to pay 20% of their benefit cost while union employees do not.  Yes, management does get a bonus at the end of the year but it never covers the cost of the benefits.  Confusing and conflicting goals are difficult to obtain as all of them are a priority which means none are a priority.  Fuel hedging is out of control, buy high instead of buying low.   Senior leadership takes a back seat to employee and customer complaints, leading to a poor product.

pros: Work is interesting and challenging, and benefits are great.  Most of the people are very enthusiastic about their work, and love airlines and the airline industry.  The work-life balance is great, which gives you an opportunity to travel on weekends or socialize with friends and colleagues.
cons: A big, lumbering bureacracy that often has trouble adapting quickly to market changes.  This is further exacerbated by union work rules and pay structures that make cost savings difficult.  Senior management spends too much time chasing the industry "leaders", often at the expense of United's success

review_title: It's been a long fall from Great to Mediocre
job_title: Airplane Pilot Or Copilot in Washington, DC
pros: Good benefits package, including medical, dental, vision and FSA.
cons: Zero advancement in 9 years.  Management intent on adopting easiest processes/products, not best.  Feels like hostile takeover by Continental management, all firmly convinced that they know how to run an airline, despite their inexperience with international and wide-body aircraft, and the compelling evidence to the contrary, evidenced by big mistakes in systems and software integration.

review_title: A prominent international brand, but with some significant challenges of a rapidly changing industry.
pros: Some good people, both at corporate staff and in customer service and operations.  Good benefits, of course.  Most salaries adequate.  Wages for line workers are superior in the industry, but not always reciprocated with loyalty and positive attitudes.
cons: The attraction of working with some good people was diminished to a degree by the heavy and overpopulated corporate bureaucracy, and by ponderous inertia in "doing things as we always have."  United is a textbook case of a company that needs to become much leaner, faster, and more entrepreneurial in strategy and management; and more unfailingly customer-centric at the airports and onboard.  Plain vanilla isn't acceptable.

review_title: Travel benefits not worth the hassle
pros: Transportation is an interesting field, and airlines are an important piece of the global transportation network, so the work is interesting. The flight benefits allow you to travel to cool places for free (if you can get a seat).
cons: The merger with CO has been an overwhelming disappointment. Poorly executed from the beginning, even after several years there are readily apparent divisions within the company between the two sides. Systems integration continues to be an ongoing disaster. Attempting to get things done across different workgroups is a frustrating exercise, many senior leaders seem to be more concerned with the path that absolves them from any accountability rather than pursuing the correct strategy. Flight load factors continue to rise and over the years it has become much more difficult to use the flight benefits. If you like spending hours at the airport on edge staring at the standby list, then this is the job for you.

review_title: Not the great airline it once was, but still a great place to work.
pros: Awesome co-workers, ability to trade on and off shifts, flight benefits. I had the opportunity to work in almost every department and in numerous stations, both domestic and international. I've worked on both the labor and management sides of the company. Overall, despite all of the negatives, I have never more thoroughly enjoyed any other work experience. Although the climate has changed a great deal since the merger, I'd still recommend UA as a great place to work if you are a plane and airline junkie like me. I am now out of the industry, and not a day goes by that I don't miss something about it.
cons: Leadership issues. Downsizing by outsourcing work to non UA employees and companies. Sometimes excessively long hours (involuntary hold over). Pay is on the low side.

review_title: Accidentally applied to the wrong job and got it.
pros: Benefits, the usual suspects are great. But the added benefits of travel make up for anything that was lacking. Being able to travel first class internationally is equal to as much as $10,000 if the ticket is right, getting it at a fraction of a fraction of the actual first class fare is pretty nice.
cons: It is a difficult job for spurts of time during the day. Over all the job is easy, but the time constraints of an "on-time" departure can be trying. It is you against the public in trying to organize a crowd into boarding in order, and storing their luggage. Pepper in some needy passengers that demand instead of ask and you are good to go.

review_title: Interview and hiring process were a little haphazard.
pros: I was very glad to be accepted for a supervisory postion within United at O'Hare. I consider myself very luck to be involved in the operation so close to the center of the United world network. The pay structure is competitive, the culture is welcoming and encourages teamwork, and the office is pleasant.
cons: From my initial application to the training process, being onboarded as a Supervisor - SOC Zone Controller has been occasionally difficult to navigate. While I understand that there are many simaultaneous personnel shifts happening within the department at once, I feel like I would have appreciated greater proactive involvement from management in the onboarding process.

job_title: User Experience Designer in Chicago, IL
pros: People there are nice, free flight benefits, business casual dress code, lots of corporate discounts. Flexible start times, and occasional work from home days.
cons: Pay is low, raises are usually 0-1.5% a year. Very little creativity. Design ideas are always "how does Delta do it". Stakeholder wants trump user needs. Poorly managed departments, employees are treated like children. Promotions are based on favoritism, not performance. Good ideas are stolen by management and sold as their own. High turnover. Flight benefits are increasingly more difficult to take advantage of.

review_title: Leadership doesn’t understand or care about UX
job_title: Senior User Experience Researcher in Chicago, IL
pros: Flight discounts, occasional free snacks
cons:
Flight benefits (standby flying) only matter once you have been at the company for 10+ years. You get the bare minimum of PTO when you start out (10 days) do you don’t even get to enjoy flying.

Worst of all - if you are a UX professional - STEER CLEAR! The digital team cares more about “test & learn” and “speed to market” than they care about crafting a great user experience. They SAY they care about the experience, but they incorporate 0 research and input from customers before redesigning major gateways to their products. Another company where UX is a buzzword and not something they truly care about.

pros:
A truly global operation with a dynamic environment.
United is capable of being the premier domestic airline of choice in the US.
cons: On a whole the company is governed by longevity/seniority. Local management is comfortable with the status-quo, talking the talk about employee development and support, but failing to genuinely walk the walk. Working all day from open door offices to support an open door policy, failing to engage in daily operation and with staff and avoiding difficult performance conversations, which would foster development, engagement and a high performance environment.

pros: Great experience and if like challenges and the all types of the public and traveling (if can get on a plane) it's a great job and eventually great pay.
cons: Was told no layoffs to employees due to the cost of the merger!  A lie!!! Since the merger over 15 stations outsourced and over 20+more to come.  They are fully replacing company employees with a contract vendor company that is underpaid and no benefits and wearing United uniforms.  A job not Career minded!  Flights are getting smaller hard to travel.

review_title: Not Just An Airline, A Career
pros:
Personal and family flight benefits are unbeatable. 
Working in headquarters in downtown Chicago. (Instead of at the airport like at other airlines.) 
Good 401k matching. 
Extremely inclusive company culture welcomes all people of all backgrounds.
Transparent Leadership always willing to answer questions honestly. 
Plenty of room to move laterally through company departments. 
Monthly bonuses for good operations.
cons:
Fewer standard holidays compared to other companies (10 per year).
Healthcare benefits are comprehensive, but more expensive than at other companies. 
Front line employees get better bonuses than corporate employees.

pros: Once merged, will be the biggest airline... lot's of places to travel to...  the FA position offers flexibility in your days off...   but the first few years of Reserve (on call) will be rough.
cons: Merger process not going well...  FA groups from the two sides are completely at odds with each other. Contract (work rules) and culture clash. Also, often a lack of respect by management which is only concerned with their bonuses and golden parachutes. Now that Tilton is out, we're halfway there... Smisek's performance is yet to be seen, but so far he's not proving to be much different than Tilton.

review_title: Having 20 + years experience, working in several departments , have seen some ups and downs.
pros: Could not ask for better co- workers, excellent flight concessions, a good pension. A unique working environment.
cons: Would give up a host of flight concessions for a couple of confirmed seats any day. Local (ie non US ) decisions rely on Chicago accounts unfortunately they don't always get the full picture and just bean count. Promotional opportunities a bit hit and miss, have received some lame excuses for not getting the job in the past. Most departments work short on resources and you get put in uncomfortable positions usually when striking a good work / life balance.

job_title: Training and Development Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: I have never in my life worked with more passionate, driven, excited people.  I worked here for 4 years and was unfortunately furloughed.  Gladly, I was able to come back to where I wanted to be and 2 years later, I am very glad of my decision.
cons: This is a big company and sometimes things move slower that we feel they need to.  There are a lot of approvals and reviews, and meetings to get things that seem fairly simple done.

pros: United can be a great place to work, it all depends on your division. The people as a whole are amazing and incredibly motivated. A very large and diverse work force which allows for a lot of great knowledge sharing. The flight benefits are also amazing.  However, some groups are just down right terrible!
cons: A LOT of bureaucracy! Senior Management is so keen on keeping control of their own fiefdoms that everyone works in silos. It impossible to get things done without including every single person's boss in an email. A lot of old school beliefs as well.  Promotion and pay increases are terrible. The pay is crap, particularly in comparison to what you can make from leaving and then coming back.

review_title: Smisek has them on the right track, he just needs to make sure his message gets to the line employees.
pros: Flight benefits, working in Chicago and the majority of the people you work with.
cons: Archaic organizational structure limits innovation and improvement at United, everyone just does the safe conservative thing because its easy and they'll never lose their job. Its not a high performance environment right now and hopefully that changes as the integration of CO and UA continues to take place.

pros:
•Very easy job if you like to be outside 

• if you like to be active job is for you 

• very flexible. You have a set schedule but you can trade shifts and pick up with your co-workers. So you can really create your own schedule if you want. 

• your co-workers will get you through the day. 

• Free flights, Discounted flights, Discounted hotels!!!!! 

• very competitive! You have to get flights out on time if that is for you, you will love this.
cons:
•Poor Management feels like they don’t care about you.

• working in the rain “But hey it’s a outside job.”

• very competitive. If a flight goes out late you can get in a lot of trouble.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Chicago, IL
pros: I love people. Their stories and integrity will always amaze me and TEACH me. Do not judge a book by its cover until you've walked a mile through it. I've worked in high paying management positions where stress can get to you over time... and where you are also stuck in your own office for long lengths of time with little to no human interaction.  I will never go back to that. I took a chance at change taking the job I have now with United. I decreased my pay substantially and increased by commute 100%.  Why? At first it was about people and wanting to be around more in general. And now seeing the return in the form of smiles and thank you is one of the best gifts and highest paying perks a person can unknowingly receive. Me and most of my co-workers go above and beyond for each person we interact with. United is your family when you are not home or have none. There is always someone, somewhere for you if you need it. United through it all!
cons: Must have thick skin, empathy, sympathy.  The reason the average person travels (leisure, vacation, etc.) isn't the reason others may be traveling (tragedy). As in any customer service job.  If you don't have some form of compassion that you can hold a grip on you may not last.  Remember the story and use it as your guide. Also remember that the airport and operation never closes.  You may be required to work at any given time or day.  Most don't mind but some do and I've seen great people leave over that alone.  Remember that is a huge choice you make when accepting the offer for employment. Do not waste their time and money on training, uniforms, badging, etc. if you don't think you can work late hours, holidays, your birthday,  your kids birthday, etc.  You can find people to trade with but it's never a guarantee.

pros: United currently has a great management team that is focused on maintaining the things the company does well and improving those it doesn't. Suggestions and ideas from employees are encouraged. In my department, everyone is treated like a capable professional and not micromanaged. It was shocking to me when I started how much energy the company has, given it's been around so long! People are excited to work here. It makes coming to work so much more enjoyable.
cons: It's a big company, so agility is (not surprisingly) a challenge. That said, the management team is taking steps to address it. This isn't a place for someone with thin skin since the airline industry is always in the news. Your friends and family will come to you if there's a negative article. It probably also isn't the place for someone who enjoys a slow pace, as there's lots of work to be done!

review_title: Excellent routes, values, poor upper management
pros:
Best routes domestically and internationally, wide variety of domestic and international bases for Flight Attendants
Incredible flexibility in schedule and union representation with hard fought work rules implementation.
Great pay and plenty of flying for holders (instant trading)
Excellent commitment to Eco-Skies program
Consistent supporter of minority groups and progressive values (LGBT, women, people of color) 
Personal CEO (Oscar Munoz) with great rapport and genuine concern
cons:
Terribly unpopular president (Scott Kirby) making poor decisions thinly guised under profitability
Straight Reserve for Flight Attendants resulting in long time spent on reserve
Profit over people is common
Tone dead on employee complaints (insisting everything's good despite numerous scandals and PR nightmares)

job_title: Senior User Experience Designer in Chicago, IL
pros: Flight benefits (standby travel), somewhat flexible work schedule
cons:
Lack of support from managers and leaders
No strategy or project prioritization
No desire to adopt change or modernize practices
The "business" does not care about the customer experience
Limited career advancement opportunities

review_title: The worst experience of my professional career.
job_title: Product Development Manager in Elk Grove Village, IL
pros: On the one hand, if you want to be lazy and just slide by, United Airlines is the place to work. You can get by doing barely anything. Your co-workers are aware of it, but not management.
cons: If you actually care about your work, United Airlines is not the place to work. There are so many slackers, unqualified workers, overlap in job duties and superfluous personnel that it's actually really hard to get your job done. The tools and resources provided to personnel is abhorent (Airline operations however had a good repuation. I would still fly United...). The organizational structure and strategy is also a joke.

pros: Flexible Schedule.  Great Pay and Benefits.  Can commute to work from any city.  I had some great supervisors when Based in Chicago.  Very kind and wanted to see you succeed.
cons: Commuting can make the job more stressful.  Have to make sure that the flight loads accommodate a commuter's schedule.  The customer service agents are very rude in most cases.  When based in LAX and DEN the supervisors were terrible and were looking to get rid of you.  It all depends on where you are based.

review_title: It is like this...except when it is like that
pros:
*Global brand 
* Large network
* there are some humane and competent middle managers ( but they are few and far between )
cons:
* very bitter incumbent coworkers.  They are angry and management, angry and new hires, angry at customers...just plain angry
* policy and procedure changes on a regular basis...the only thing consistent is inconsistency.  
*organization is obsessed with metrics with little concern over human factor impact on customers or employees
*willingness to outsource anything and everything to the lowest bidder with little consideration for quality control and impact on the brand

review_title: Under to be a good place to work.
pros: Good people, especially on the United side of this merger. Very Professional, on the United side of the merger. Concerned with actually providing a great product and sticking to their word with employees, on the United side of the merger.
cons:
Poor decision making.
Hostile environment if you disagree or have the audacity to suggest anything other than what management wants to do.
Loads of scabs.
Management uses words a lot and seldom follow up with concrete actions.
Obviously run by a lawyer who is not a leader.
Inability to think outside a very small box.
Peter Principle in action.
Centralized management that cannot be adaptive to real day to day operations.
Very immature management entrenched in their ways, no creativity. Like a child holding its breath.
Management that easily spends millions on itself but is overly stingy with its employees needs. Again, severe lack of leadership.

pros: United has great benefits and an extremely flexible schedule.  You can work minimum hours at part time status and still receive full medical, dental, and flying benefits.  With the right manager and team, the experience is pretty positive.
cons: Airport operations are all unionized and it is hard to cultivate a change in work culture.  High seniority agents that do not contribute much get paid more than their eager, high energy, and well performing new hires due to strong local unions.  There is minimal growth opportunities for eager new hires unless you are willing to move to Houston or Chicago.  Wages and salaries start very low.

review_title: A Career That Made My Life and Me
job_title: International Flight Attendant in London, England
pros: Met my wife and saw the world
cons: Permanently disabled on the job as verified by radiological data post injury but denied by UAL though impairments from the onboard injury led to my termination 4 weeks prior to full retirement after being denied 4 weeks FMLA for the cervical rehab I was in. 55-year-olds with pre-existing conditions inflicted from work and a WC record in Chicago superior court mean I was wise to buy LTD and not trust my employer.

review_title: Fly for free, serve a few drinks, see the world!
pros: benefits!! free travel! You basically work as an independent contractor, you receive an assignment, or bid for an assisgnment, and then you show up to work and fly that trip. There are no reports to turn in, ( unless something goes wrong!) For example, I have not turned in a report in over 2 years! So there is a lot of independance, and you basically have half the month off, its great!
cons: very impersonal, the management only contacts you when something is wrong! Very little positive feedback from any one in management

pros: Great benefits for flights, relatively flexible schedule, matching 401K, good health benefits. Very smart people to work with. Challenging environment with many moving parts.
cons: More and more development is being sent offshore and internal dev teams are being consolidated or moved. One must play the political game with managers to see any kind of career advancement. The best advice I heard after I left is to market yourself to everyone, not just your manager. Professional reviews are vague and improvements are not acknowledged.  Training is scarce and usually done on your own time. Lateral movement is difficult and promotion is rare.

pros: Writing a second review since I’ve been promoted (new job technically) and because they just introduced a new parental leave policy. It’s a good company with tons of career opportunities. Ideal company for a recent graduate or someone without too many strings because you can travel to cool places, build your resume, learn how a large, complex company works, try a few different jobs/departments, enjoy Chicago, etc. Hours aren’t too crazy for most teams.
cons: Pay is a little lower than other industries. My promotion raise was disappointingly low. The CEO is a little phony but that role is honestly one for a politician so it works ok. Overall good place to work. A little stingy.

review_title: Proud to be a part of the United family
job_title: Airport Operations Coordinator in San Francisco, CA
pros: Not just working for a huge company it feels more like being part of a large family. With every department holding its own, the company comes together in a whole. There are a lot of positive influences here. People who I work with always greet me in passing. Health packages are a huge plus. Flying perk, who doesn't like to fly?
cons: I really cannot complain about what I do. My team makes it rewarding.

review_title: Great if you meet the bar
job_title: Financial Analyst in San Francisco, CA
pros: You can travel for free if the plane is not oversold which it commonly is.  People in management are nice.  Good appareciation events and incentives.
cons: Some of the people have a bare bones minimum education.  Only some of the management team have higher education.  You can forget admins having any higher learning and most have come from prior union jobs that stick to the status quo.  There is a lack of accountability and initiative or any forward thinking.  There is still a subUnited and subContinental mentality.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Los Angeles, CA
pros:
There are many perks and pros for working an airline. 
• Flight benefits (with horrible seniority, I got better flights using our benefits on other airlines)
• Meeting new people 
• Life changing opportunity 
• OKAY starting pay, the pay increases with the years but that takes forever. 
• Training is long + helpful. 
• Fairly sage job (unless you work in the lobby) 
• Perfect career job
cons:
• United is STRICTLY seniority based which can make everything hard seeing as how NO ONE QUITS or TRANSFERS. 
• United can care LESS about personal opinion & work environment. 
• Employees ESPECIALLY senior employees DON’T really like to work or help other employees and customers. most are not “the friendly skies” , they also feel ENTITLEMENT! many don’t follow simple rules that apply to everyone.

review_title: A good and stable company to work for
pros: Overall UAL is a good company to work for, the communication is pretty transparent and they do pay very well and have very good benefits.  The environment is decent, though the "cube farm" style of the HQ is not very conducive to productivity.  The people are great, friendly and most are excellent to work with.
cons: Many departments still subscribe to the idea that working from home or remotely is bad.  You need to be at your desk or using a vacation/sick day.   Cost Cutting is the norm, dont spend any money is the usual way.

review_title: Good company as long as you know what you are getting in to.
job_title: Account Manager, Passenger Sales in Chicago, IL
pros: Excellent benefits, great people to work with, and of course the flight benefits are unbeatable.
cons: Salary will always be lower than comparable job in any other industry, extreme boom and bust business cycle leads to job instability, HR policy of hiring people with MBA degrees who have absolutely no real world airline experience or business sense and then placing them in decision and policy setting positions.  The company places WAY too much weight on an MBA degree and not enough on a persons abilities or experience.

pros: Family environment. People care. Fun place to work. Growth opportunities when available.
cons: Salary is mid grade compared to peers and other large organizations it’s size. New CISO lacks communication, direction and leadership. Was chosen as a backfill as the previous CISO who left that was beloved! It’s become a toxic environment and even though it’s a tough climate due to Coronavirus and company is taking heavy losses having poor leadership In Security organization doesn’t help. The CEO Oscar is phenomenal let’s see how the incoming CEO does. Cannot work from home (except now due to Coronavirus). Senior IT Leadership is against. Sad in today’s day and age and now they have no choice. Hope they will become wise after this.

review_title: Passion will drive an airline career, but this company makes that difficult
pros: Immediate departmental colleagues are outstanding, contributions can be recognized but this varies on location/supervisor. Travel benefits are always a nice lifestyle to have, but have been gutted after the merger for management employees. Truly a globally diverse company.
cons: Toxic culture post-merger, UA is really struggling to find an identity out of the combined United and Continental cultures. Too much focus on pleasing Wall Street and not the employees or customers. HQ is terribly bureaucratic, hierarchical, and risk-averse. Profit sharing for management was reduced greatly for 2014, to the point of being a joke at the expense of other workgroups.

pros: Is one of the largest international air carriers in the world. Prior to the consolidation w/ Continental airlines this job was one of the most coveted jobs in the industry. The company took care of its employees by providing a respectable level of earnings and Above average health care benefits as a demonstration of a job well done by its employees. Was a GREAT place to work.
cons: Consolidation of the 2 airlines was the worst pride and confidence destroyer in the history of this Airline. Allowing Continental management to assume control of the working operations. The appreciation of employees and their moral has gone to the lowest level in the history of the airline and its industry.

pros: Best benefits I've encountered in the corporate world. Low to no cost Dental, Vision, Life & Health,  Competitive vacation, can request and awarded 30-89 days off (no pay but you keep your benefits)  Pay is fairly decent after the first 5 years.
cons: Contractual benefits, et al are  negotiated by the union and management.  Therefore you have to depend on union to negotiate practically everything except your hiring & firing (firing is bit of a tricky area) You give up your rights to be treated as an individual - which means sometimes you may be sacrificed for what union may believe is the greater good.  A lot of responsibility but no authority.

review_title: United Airlines is not a nice place to work
pros: Diversity of personnel and projects
cons: UAL is a tefrritorial and narcissistic environment that encourages personnel to not be open, collaborative or forthcoming. People own their areas of expertise and are reluctant to share information, ideas and design concepts for fear or reprisal by their colleagues and management. The longer term employees dominate and manipulate the newer ones and there is a definite hierarchy of influence and authority. All in all, it is not a fun place to work... especially in the IT sectors of the company.

review_title: A place where good careers go to die.
job_title: Senior Systems Engineer in Elk Grove Village, IL
pros: Near-free standby travel used to be a good perk, but now you can't get on a plane to save your life.  If you want to go somewhere and not work very hard and get left alone, this is the place for you.  Underachievers' haven.
cons: Nobody seems to care about anything.  After 2 pay cuts and 50% layoff in department, still being told you need to work harder.  There are some super people with outdated skills working their butts off because they fear for their jobs while others enjoy getting paid for surfing the web all day.  They have recognition awards which are basically a way to make 90% of the employees feel like they're even more underappreciated.

pros: The flight benefits were great...when you could take advantage of them.
cons:
Unless you are obsessed with travel, there is no benefit to working at United. I consistently witnessed deplorable behavior (backbiting, scheming) being rewarded with promotions. There is a constant air of negativity amongst employees, and everyone is worried about yet another reorg. Employees are often reorg'd into jobs they didn't sign up for and aren't suited for, thus leading them to total misery and failure. Talent gets wasted at United (see: large UX team, very little visual change to the website since 2006. 2006!!!!!).

I also worked for Continental Airlines and while working there was not as lucrative, the culture was much healthier. We were generally happy employees with great travel benefits who were proud of the work we did. 

I also noticed that the Glassdoor rating for UA is artificially bloated by fake reviews. Don't buy it, people.

pros:
Travel benefits are so great!  My mom went to Taipei yesterday, my dad is going to London tomorrow, and I am going to check out Brazil this weekend.  That's just the typical week in our lives.
Also, the airline industry is incredibly interesting, so most employees are genuinely interested in their jobs.
cons: It's frustrating that the company strategy is mostly focused on short-term shareholder returns.  It sucks that anytime I tell people that I work for United Airlines, they are bound to tell me how horrible our customer service is and how unreliable our flight operations are.   I can't even disagree with them, because I get the sense that we are more about shareholder returns than about creating a wonderful service.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Chicago, IL
pros: Coworkers are really friendly and there seems to be very little corporate politics compared to other companies of the size. Work/life balance is also very good, especially for finance. Obviously travel perks are good, but much better if you have seniority which takes a very long time.
cons: Most of the strategy seems to come from the top with little challenge/strategy from middle managers which limits the ideas and has created many changes with senior management changes. The infrastructure is also dated, which can be pretty frustrating at times.

job_title: Ramp Agent in San Francisco, CA
pros: I reported to my first day of work and gave my trainer bad news about my driver license suspension. Since it was going to take longer than expected the trainer told me I can resign and come back when I get everything fixed. You can't work on the ramp without a driver license otherwise it wouldn't be an issue.
cons: When I received my check in the mail it came with a separation note saying that I'm not eligible for rehire. This kind of broke my heart because one, I was told thing, and two, I was already bummed that I couldn't work for United like I've been wanting to for the longest time.

job_title: Airport Sales Agent in Atlanta, GA
pros: I was with Continental and retired soon after the merger It was an amazing job. I loved working with passengers. Cranky ones usually had a good reason for it. LOVED the flight benefits. Loved the flexibility with schedule, location etc. I really loved my job.
cons: It became United and everything changed, sadly.  So many former employees have told me to be glad that I'm gone.  Continental was in the top 100 companies to work for for many years, then United merger happened. Employees are all unhappy.  Management is terrible. Thousands of positions have been outsourced and the outsourced folks do the same job with no flight benefits.

review_title: Great company, positive energy and core values.
job_title: Customer Service Supervisor in Chicago, IL
pros:
Positive work culture.  Oscar has made an effort to change United for the better! Everyone makes it an effort to make you feel like you are a part of a family and have been friendly .  

There are opportunities all over and room to grow! If you are a go getter this is the place to be !  Benefits start right away !
cons: It can be crazy during weather and holidays. Schedule is based on seniority so if you are a new hire , expect nights. Training is OJT.. do not expect a classroom and you have to be willing to put in the work.   They do follow a good pattern in ORD . 5 on next week 4 on.

review_title: Dream in the air; nightmare on the ground.
pros: The travel benefits make the job worth it. You are assigned on trips both domestic and international, and can travel unlimited anywhere they fly on your off time. You meet amazing people and experience amazing things in short time. It's a unique and exhilarating lifestyle.
cons: The salary is terrible. The workers' rights are terrible. Pension is non-existent. Employees are treated unfairly. Management is so out of touch with different forces. They are incompetent of connecting their goals with those of other departments. The lifestyle is too erratic and makes it impossible for employees to plan anything. Management is the worst element of this job and this company.

review_title: terrible for seeing ipay...websites dont work..app dont work
pros: i get paid one day early that is the only pro
cons: the ipay app on my phone does not show what was taken out for what...it's very complicated and you cant see deductions ..always says its not available it's a joke...the desk top you can see deductions but very confusing..current deductions mixed with year to date deductions and it constantly makes you change password but when you go to change the password the website dont come up...good for companies terrible for employees..ive never had a problem getting my money thats the only plus..early never late but you cant log in 90% of the time...

pros: Top out pay is great.  Until the next pay cut.  There are no other positives to this company.
cons: All of the culture from Continental has been crushed.  Everyone that now works for the "New United" is in fear for their job.  Management literally hates you, if you have work at the ticket counter, gate, slave on the ramp, or fly on an airplane,   We are not valued as employees.  We are not considered an asset.  We are the scum of of the company.  There is no humanity coming from Willis Tower.  Management in Chicago is dead set on pleasing the shareholders and themselves only.  Screw the customers, screw the rank and file employees.  We are the laughing stock of the airline industry.  Lufthansa must be truly embarrassed to have any association with United.

pros: Flight benefits, good shift start and time
cons: This is my 3rd tour of duty, but we collectively cannot get hired on.  We are a returning group of 18 from over 100 previous employees that have been brought on from Summer 15 and Winter 15, and now summer 2016.  We've been given explanation as to why we aren't being hired, but it seems that at some point a high consideration would be given to us because of our work performance first and foremost, and our diligent determination as well.  Permanent mployees seem to be in better spirits with the looming new contract, so things aren't as bad.  I would hope that if they don't keep us as permanent employees this time that they DON'T throw a "going away celebration"??

pros: Flight benefits were really the only reason I stayed as long as I did.
cons: Not much room for advancement.  You get logjammed with 30 other people trying to move up.  It's also a culture about feelings.  You can suck at your job, but as long as treat people like they're your best friend and never correct/help them, you will be fine

review_title: Can be a great place to work if you are under a good Director or Manager.
pros: Good pay and benefits for the most part. The flight benefits are great if you can get on a plane flying standby. It is getting harder and harder getting on flights anymore.
cons: Don't believe everything you hear from the upper level executives of the company. They are looking out for themselves and the company more than they are looking out for the employees. They put on a great face when they see you in person but will stab you in the back once they leave.

review_title: U N I T E D - take the good with the bad.
job_title: Project Manager in Elk Grove Village, IL
pros: Flight benefits!  Interesting time to be in the airline industry.  Most people are generally easy to work with and it is great working for a company that everyone knows.  There are always new opportunities for new projects or promotion, although it can be very political.
cons: Large environment with many departments not communicating effectively.  Lack of concrete leadership strategy and goals.  Everything is "confidential".  Too many people have been there for 30+ years and hold a grudge for new people who haven't yet "put their time in".  It takes forever to get anything changed or accomplished.  Meetings about meetings...

review_title: Once again the CEO of United Airlines lets down his employees!
pros: at the time i was hired in 2000, it was the biggest & best airline in terms of pay & benefits for pilots in the industry with plenty of opportunity for growth & advancement.
cons: We now have completely inept management that even after taking everything they could from pilots like 43% pay cut & terminated our pensions at considerable savings to the company plus other cuts in pay & benefits to just about all employee groups, this company still can't turn a profit.  It just one blunder after another & one missed opportunity after another.  However, there always seems to be enough money for the ceo & his management team to pull down millions!

pros: Flight benefit !  Great colleagues .
cons:
We lived in cut-throat environment.  Management does not focus on long term solutions.  New blood were brought in to replace hard head managers. Instead of bringing in new ideas and approaches, those new bosses heartlessly destroyed knowledge and expertise that were well established, over and over. They got rid of good and royal veteran employees. Then, they moved on to next level and left the company.  No work ethics here! New bosses could bring his/her allies to replace old employees. Regardless of how good the old employees or his/her skill set or performance or year of service. The reason to cut was "new leadership business direction".
High turnover in HR department.  They being laid off first.

pros:
Challenging work.  Great people who really care about the industry, company and coworkers.  Company is genuinely working to make things better all over the company.  Lots of people have been here a long time.  
Travel priviledges are the best perk!  Solid benefits package.
cons: Cyclical industry (although we are starting to level this out as an industry).  Sometimes, the long tenures of employees can be a negative.  Many of these long-term employees are cynical and would rather complain and cast blame than do their little part to make the company better.

review_title: Great Flight Benefits everything else needs improvement!
pros: Flight benefits, office location, and the new CEO cares about front-line employees
cons: The company only cares about front-line employees not corporate, poor vacation for new hires (2 weeks), low salaries, horrible culture (even with the new CEO) since most of the bad senior leaders won't retire/leave and all the good leaders seem to leave since decisions are usually based on bias and friendships. United likes to "talk the talk" by saying they are focusing on "meritocracy" and "trust" but does nothing to back it up with actions to change the culture for management employees.

pros: The doors are still open
cons: Inability to appreciate the historical aspects of what works and what does not.

review_title: Nice place to work if you are in the right group.
job_title: Account Manager, MileagePlus in Chicago, IL
pros: Allows for some extraordinary life experiences with travel benefits, when you can get on a flight. The work is interesting and challenging, and you will be surrounded by other smart people. Overall the benefits package is good.
cons: With consolidation with CO and UA staff, almost impossible to move up. Even lateral moves are tough. MileagePlus leadership only recognizes white males with MBAs in their 30s. In general, the airline industry is lower paying than others.

job_title: Flight Attendant in Las Vegas, NV
pros: If you love people, have a great attitude and live for spontaneity.. this is the job for you! You get the opportunity to see places you’ve never seen, move to cities you never thought you would and meet some of the greatest people. This job will change your life. The benefits are great too.
cons: If you have responsibilities on the ground it can be very challenging. We have a straight reserve system currently (meaning you’re “on call”) so when you’re just starting out you need to be prepared to leave at any moment. Also, it’s very likely you will have to move to one of the bases so be prepared to move. I started this job single, no kids and ready for an adventure so it was all very exciting for me.

review_title: Good place to work, decent compensation and benefits
pros: Employee travel benefits are great. Mid/Senior management compensation is excellent. Airline industry is complex, so lots of interesting opportunities and problems to solve. If one is looking for challenge in their role, there is lots!
cons:
With each new change in Senior Management, lots of things change since they are given complete freedom. This could become disruptive esp with lots of management changes have happened the past few years.
HQ divided among multiple locations and lots of facilities moves is reason for loss of productivity.
If one has worked at United long enough, one can see the same projects/ideas/cycles float every few years - deja vu.

pros: There are great benefits when it comes to flying and for the most part, a lot of good employee's who made the days go by quickly.  I enjoyed the time I was there for the most part.
cons: Upper management (not middle) needs a lot of work.  They don't see the big picture and seem to just be interested in those you are willing to stick there noses way high into you know what.  There were a lot of good people overlooked that should have been considered for promotions.

review_title: At this time, they aren't keeping up with the 21st century with their computer system and hoping it gets resolved.
pros: The health benefits are very good...negotiated by our union. The pay is also good for non-degree positions.  Most employees are great to work with!!
cons: The employees don't get choices about alot of frontline decisions. We aren't conducting business the way we did as United; now everything is the Continental way...which isn't always the best way. Wish we took more of the best from each airline, instead of ALL Continental's way. It will take time to smooth out the animosity between UA workers and CO workers.

pros: Flight benefits, compensation, and coworkers.
cons: Senior Leadership and all Divisional Leadership, HR, and corporate culture.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in San Francisco, CA
pros: The company as a whole is just a plus! The culture is very conservative and professional. They prepare you before you're put on the floor with training classes (if you're lucky, you'll get Kealani). You meet so many AMAZING people who are willing and ready to help guide you in whatever direction you want to go in this gigantic company. The company is transparent with its customers and employees. This company is amazing because of so many reasons but my number one reason is because they honestly care about the employees and take care of them. It's not just about the customer. It's about the customer AND the employees.
cons: The only downside is the scheduling. You bid for shifts and seniority if everything! Another reason to get in early and stay in (haha!).

review_title: United Airlines Pilot review of operation.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Despite the recent high profile customer service issue, United is a great place to work.  Pilots have access to many different bases around the country and the ability to fly the newest and best maintained aircraft in the sky with the best contract in the industry.  The pilot group is represented by a union that supports our ability to make decisions that are in the best interest of the safety of each flight.  Customers never know how important this support of pilots is to ensure that each flight is operated with safety foremost in the mind of their pilot rather than what some manager believes is in the best interest of the company’s bottom line.
cons: The continual boom and bust cycle of the airline industry.

review_title: Great Culture, Excellent Recruiting, Interviewing & Offer Process
job_title: Manager, Human Resources in Chicago, IL
pros: Welcoming culture, friendly faces, hard-working, focused colleagues. Despite recent bad press, inside there is a real turnaround happening under the new CEO, the employee energy is palpable and everyone I've encountered wants to do the right thing for employees and customers.
cons: At Willis Tower there is one bathroom per floor and it's always jammed and gets a little dirty, quickly.  Cost of health & insurance benefits is very high, but you could consider it offset by the generous 401k match and employee travel benefits.

job_title: Senior Project Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Benefits are OK, Flight Benefits are good only if you have at least 10 years of seniority.  LGBT friendly, if that's your thing, especially "L" friendly in the IPMO.
cons: Lying and deceit has never left.  Earlier this year, after many faithful years, loyal, knowledgeable IPMO employees with many years of service were shown the door.   So called 'restructuring and eliminating positions'.  After a few short months, the IPMO has more management employees as contractors and outsiders are being hired.   Don't ever feel good or secure while at United, no matter what you are told.

pros: The schedule flexibility is great. I've traveled to a lot of beautiful places thanks to this job, both on and off duty. Wonderful place to work if you want to see new places.
cons: The hours can be brutal (up to 16hrs on duty and you only get paid for the time you're actually in the air). As a reserve you have no control over things like working daytime shifts and redeyes within the same week. Most benefits are seniority-based, from salary to flying benefits. If you want to get the best out of the company, you'll have to make it a career and enjoy what they have to offer when you've been here thirty years.

review_title: Among the best internships out there.
pros: Extremely important work given to intern with 0 experience. Colleagues took immense time to teach me everything they knew. Ability to fly to Europe, Hawaii, ...everywhere for a token fee, every weekend, on standby. Lots and lots of freedom, great team structure, and the ideas I presented were implemented with little hesitation. Smart managers with diverse experiences; lots of former consultants who sought a better life-work balance are working in management.
cons: No clear path how to advance through airline. Worked during United-Continental merger, so advancement opportunities were murky. Internship program is small, but flight-benefits for interns is the best benefit out there!!!

review_title: Mediocrity is the goal for united.com
job_title: E-commerce product development manager in Chicago, IL
pros:
Great work/life balance
Good benefits, including free flights (on standby)
Airline industry is fun
Flight operations are solid
cons:
E-commerce is not a focus of the company
Product management takes orders from other groups, does not drive strategy
United website is built poorly and has low customer satisfaction, and no effort has been made to fix it
Continental site is outdated and will be the platform for the new joint site
Major growing pains merging the two companies
Culture is hierarchical and old-school
Management is unapproachable and does nothing with feedback from staff
Social media barely exists
Merchandising rules the online strategy, user experience is the last priority

review_title: Excellent career opportunity, exposure, challenge at United Airlines
pros: Good ability to try new things (the airline has many divisions so employees can get exposure to whatever type of business interests you) and management is supporting of developing talent; hours are great (corporate standard 8a-5p or 9a-6p); competitive salary; flight benefits; challenging and interesting airline industry; the cross-divisional nature of the work is tremendous -- never stuck in one spot/area without exposure to multiple divisions and/or impacting on-going projects.
cons: Need to network to build your brand and be recognized within the company (fairly standard); desired opportunities subject to availability; can be cuts depending on economy.

review_title: Very conservative company where who you know is more important than how well you perform
pros: Of course the free flying perks. You can go almost anywhere in the Word almost for free, sometimes first class if you are lucky! But you need to have the actual time to do that.
cons: One of the most political organizations I ever worked for. And discrimination is rampant, and is everywhere to be seen for who wants to see it.

pros: Globally recognized brand with large customer impact within the airline industry.
cons: Lots of issues post merger between Continental and United. The disgruntled employee workforce is because senior leadership lacks a clear vision for the merged organization. Taking much of the culture and operational processes from Continental, which was the smaller corporation approximately 45,000 employees was not suitable with a larger enterprise of United, which was almost twice the size.

job_title: Airport Customer Service Agent in Houston, TX
pros:
Flexible schedule, I can work as much as I want or as little as the minimum required hours per month.  Great coworkers, so many that you don't get to know them all, but everyone is very friendly.
I work in Houston in the international arrivals area and I get to see and meet many people from all over the world. Travel benefits are great.
cons: They have a points system for sick days and tardies, the amount is only 6 or 7 a year,  if you use them all you are fired.

pros: Travel is great of course. Nearly free. Flying for a living also great. The workers in the company are the reason you come in every day. They/we labor through the day trying to keep the operation safe and friendly.
cons: Company pride and team spirit are as low as you can get. Reason: the company is being treated like the CEO's personal stock portfolio and ATM, rather than a living/breathing entity. Nothing new in today's world of corporate raids and ridiculous bonuses for consistent poor performance.

review_title: The merger combined the worst of both companies, not the best of both companies.
pros: Flight benefits (though utilizing them is difficult if you can't travel at 6 am on Tuesdays). Lots of fun events related to company sponsorships.  Working with colleagues and customers around the globe from different industries.
cons: Lack of accountability -- you can have fun if you can manage to endure the mind-numbing lack of progress and innovation stemming from a complete desire to just want everyone to get along, and ensuing lack of accountability.  It was really shockingly dysfunctional in that regard.

review_title: It WAS a great place to work
pros:
Competative salary
Travel benefits
Great Coworkers
Ability to trade off shifts makes for flexible schedule
cons:
Only safe customer service jobs are at the hub cities
Outsourcing much of the labor force
Management is clueless
Top heavy company paying millions in bonuses to upper management but outsourcing jobs because of budget cuts
No real job security anymore

job_title: Air Traffic Controller in Newark, NJ
pros: Travel benefits.  It appears the company is heading in the right direction with the new CEO, Munoz.
cons: The Newark airport is not a convenient location to work; it is difficult for both drivers and commuters (via public transportation.)  The root cause to its public transportation issues is that neither the PATH nor the NJ Transit rail line stops directly at the terminal area; one needs to take the Air Train, which adds adds a $5 cost to access the terminal and has many mechanical issues of its own.

review_title: Awesome people for the most part.  It does have the standard airline industry painpoints (you'll find them everywhere).
pros: I absolutely love working for and with many individuals and teams.  The people are definitely what have kept me around, as well as understanding/forgiving work conditions.
cons: Department silos can run very tall, and in contrast to the pros, some individuals refuse to function as team players due to some misconceived notion of "job security."  This isn't so much a UAL problem, as it is a workforce problem...

pros: flight benefits and generous 401K
cons: You will be on reserve until the second coming of someone's savior or until the earth is swallowed by the sun, which ever comes first. The company is not held accountable for breaking work rules in the contract. Pay is considerably low once you realize how many hours you are at work vs what you are actually being paid for. THE UNION IS USELESS AND STEALS 50 BUCKS FROM YOUR PAY CHECK TO PAY PEOPLE TO SIT IN AN OFFICE RATHER THAN ACTUALLY WORKING AS A FLIGHT ATTENDANT!

pros: People in the airline business are passionate about the airlines.  Great people to work with.  Free plastic forks and spoons.  No charge to use the bathroom.  Flight benefits if you want to go to Iowa City.
cons: Management no longer communicates to employees.  Mid-level management will not even look at you when they pass you in the hall.  Profit sharing cut in half and raises don't keep up with cost of living.  Can't get on an airplane to use flight benefits.

review_title: Had a great experience, met great people, recommend waiting out the merger
pros: I have seen many people move around in the company, so you get different kinds of experience without having to go through an interview with another company - you still need to interview internally, though. The people I worked with were mostly very nice to work with. But it is a large company, so your experience may vary.
cons: I was told that the pay was below industry standards for "generic jobs" such as IT jobs. But I never felt the need to investigate. Financial situation lead to lay-offs from time to time, but I believe with all the mergers and bankruptcies in the industry the supply/demand situation will improve.

review_title: Very Impersonal,  Anonymous company-no personal relationships, connections or recognition for a job well done.
pros: There are no superiors to work with or to breathe down your neck. You are expected to do a good job and peers police each other as a team effort. Very easy to work here without being involved in corporate drama or preferential treatment being an issue..
cons: You rarely work with the same people twice Employees are cogs in the machine. You are a number. You can go a lifetime career without being noticed if you show up on time and do your assigned flights. There is nobody to connect with unless you go out of your way to make your own.

pros: See the world while working. Not confined to an office. Stress free career unless you are a commuter, (fly to work instead of drive which is extremely stressful).
cons: Please be aware that pilots and flight attendants work a full time 20 hours a week vs the 40 hour week for ground staff.  That cuts that hourly wage in half compared to ground staff. F/a's starting out are eligible for food stamps and housing assistance, making around $14,000 a year in salary.

review_title: Manage customer-facing policies and ensure the united voice is consistent and friendly throughout the company.
job_title: Manager, Customer Experience in Chicago, IL
pros: Travel benefits, growth opportunities, recent investment in developing and growing strong leaders, recent hiring of Oscar has increased morale and given us hope with the unions.
cons: Unfair internal hiring practices, union division, continued post-merger pains prevent us from moving forward.  There is still a large salary variance and end of year performance is on a weighting scale and there is still too much focus on allowing too many people to be in an exceeds category.

job_title: Ramp Agent/Customer Service in Santa Ana, CA
pros: Have had good experience in my last location before transfer to john wayne airport ramp.
cons: Station is hiring with the intention of firing or not passing new hires on probation making low staffing issues which gives ramp lead lots of overtime . If you do pass probation you will face harassment until you quit or transfer. I also was told not to talk about very serious safety issues. I opted to transfer because my safety and the safety of others is more important.   I tried to follow company reporting all the way up to CEO Oscar Munoz without any luck. This CEO likes to talk about diversity but is setting us back 50 years by allowing this discrimination. Apply at a different station until they clean up this station.

review_title: A company in the midst of transformation
pros: Working hard to be one of the best airlines in the world/ benchmarking itself against some of the best companies in the world.  Lots of retirements and new blood with non- aviation viewpoints/ good opportunity for advancement for the right people/ culture is a priority/ valuing diversity is also a priority/ flight benefits are the most awesome thing EVER.
cons: Lots of organizational movement can make it hard to feel settled/  aviation changes quickly so a go fast but be nimble mindset is essential/ rapid growth hard to manage

pros: Fellow employees are great people to work with, and it's still fun to fly airplanes all over the world. Despite years of abuse by senior management, despite staffing levels that have been cut deep into the bone, and despite massive pay and benefit cuts, the rank-and-file employees still carry out their jobs in a professional and conscientious manner.
cons: The absolutely terrible management: Greedy beyond compare, yet at the same time hopelessly incompetent. This has resulted in a constant sense of insecurity for the employees. The senior managers have no sense of how to run a service business, and are only interested in pillaging as much as they can from the customers, the employees, and the shareholders. Unless they are thrown out on their ears, UAL is destined to go the way of Pan Am, Eastern, Braniff, and all the other airline failures since Deregulation in 1978.

review_title: Not an inspiring place to work...no stability or security.
pros: Flight benefits are good, although almost impossible to fly standby on full flights these days.  It's an interesting industry.  Some of the people in the ranks at United are good to work with.
cons: Where to begin?  No stability.  No job security.  Limited chance for promotion.  It's a tough industry and a tough time right now, but United does a far worse job of taking care of its employees than other airlines (Southwest, Continental).  This unfortunately has translated into a cancerous mistrust by labor of Sr. Management.

review_title: Not the same industry it was 20 years ago
pros: Good people, great benefits. If you're an operational employee, you are allowed to trade you shifts allowing you to take up to a month off to travel around the world. Depending on the location you work, fellow employees are fun to work with. Health and medical are decent but that may change in 2014. Pay is okay, but sometime not worth the stress.
cons: Tools given to do your job are substandard. Express flights never run on-time and you're stuck rebooking customers in a substandard reservation system. The company is run by  what was Continental Airlines and it is horrible. It took all the bad parts of Continental and slapped the United name on it.

pros: There are no pros of working here.  People think flight benefits are good, but with stupid standby travel policy and seniority you either never get seats or waste a lot of time at the airport waiting to get one.
cons: Salary is awfully low.  Toxic work environment.  Leadership is egoistic and acts like they are king.  They don't talk to non-leadership other than giving them orders.  People don't respond to emails.  Horrible communication between employees.  People like to keep things close to their chest.  Everybody everytime is in a job saving mode.  People work in constant fear that they will lose their job any moment.  Work atmosphere plagued with fear and old school mentality.  Horrible horrible work conditions.  They not only nickel dime passengers but also employees.  Avoid this place.

pros:
> Extensive route network 
> Many chances for overtime and picking up colleagues shifts
> Ability to trade days off to have more time off
> Vacation and medical insurance is great
cons:
> Chicago management is only concerned about numbers/performance (e.g. D:0, A:0 and MBR) / they have employee recognition initiatives but do not truly care about the employee 
> Input to company is not valued, instead it is ignored or criticized 
> There is favoritism 
> Company morale continues to drop as trust is lost
> If you are not performing "well" management will immediately put you on a performance plan without giving advice or help to improve before being put on a plan. Where is the trust and care in that? 
> ORD is always playing the point the finger game with departments, ensuring their department does not get a delay.
> The culture is toxic.

review_title: It used to be a good company to work for ...
job_title: IT Project Manager in Elk Grove Village, IL
pros:
(1) The flying benefit is wonderful.  Without working for airlines, I may never fly first class internationally. 
     This benefit also covers my family (parents, spouse, and children), which makes it even better.
(2) The salary is not top in IT field.  But overall, around the average.
(3) The working load is usually reasonable.
cons:
(1) NO professional career training at all.  You are on your own!!  I have seen many colleagues left 
     because of this reason.
(2) The airline industry is very unstable in the past few years.  That means layoff happens every 2~3
     years.

review_title: Pay low at beginning but increases dramatically over time
pros: It is one of the most flexible jobs, when you compare how many days off a month you have (12 minimum).  Most "regular job" employees are lucky to have 8 in a month. Pay at the maximum 14 years is $46+ and hour (keep in mind that is flight hours), you do not work a typical 40 hour work week. Travel benefits (kids, spouse, parents partner etc), excellent healthcare, 401k
cons: Long hours at times. Away from family for days at a time. Living in hotels. It is a Union Job, so you're at their mercy when it comes to pay and benefit negotiations.

review_title: UA is great place to have work/life balance, but reactive to fuel prices
job_title: Solutions Architect in Elk Grove Village, IL
pros:
Able to work on your areas of interest.
Used to be good Flight benefits, but now flights are almost full. 
UA provides 4-6% on 401k contributions
Depending your boss, you can have flex schedule
Organized and hierarchical management. 

Definitely, ISD will be heading in right direction with new CIO and it'll be totally different from earlier leadership.
Upper leadership is changing with people who knows about technology.
cons:
No communication between management and employees.
Uncertainty and no clear vision 
Too much of outsourcing and difficult to deal with vendors.
Vendors are selected solely based on management's discretion.
UA is very reactive to market conditions, there are lot of job cuts  just to survive in the industry.

review_title: A great place to work; a great airline to fly.
job_title: Senior Category Manager in Chicago, IL
pros: Great work culture - very approachable, engaged and supportive Directors, Managing Directors, and Vice-Presidents.  Location in the Willis Tower is superb and very central for commuters.  Active projects to re-build and improve the airline are genuine and working.  Overall, a great place to work.
cons: The airline has not completed merging yet, there is still separate culture silos that need to be broken down within the corporate HQ and out in the field.

pros: There are lots of advancement opportunities, a great way to get noticed by the company as an intern, lots of respect earned by the interns, great travel privileges, and the ability to work with upper-level management to solve legitimate pressing issues for the company
cons: There is a bit of disorganization due to the large size of the corporation. For ex, it took a while for me to receive the correct software on my company computer because of the simple bureaucracy and security procedures required by the company. After this was settled, I had no problems.

job_title: Flight Attendant in San Francisco, CA
pros:
Great travel benefits for self and family. 
Work can feel like vacation sometimes
Pay increase every year
You work as much as you want or as little
cons:
Long hours, scheduling isn't great
Many politics in this airline with the merger
Need to have a lot of seniority to have the benefits of a good work schedule
You can feel like just a number in the crowd of over 20,000 flight attendants that work for this airline.
As a reserve they can roll your days off, so no plans can ever be set.
As a line holder, you have more flexibility, but can work up to 16 hour duty day, often asked to waive your rights.
Negative attitude from passengers at times due to media portrayal of airline.
Short layover hotels, not great

job_title: Ramp Serviceman in San Diego, CA
pros: The benefit package is second to none for this entry level, part time status. The company appears committed to the growth and development of its employees and offers many tools to that end for employees to access.
cons: The salary is extremely low given the cost of living where I reside. The near constant threat of outsourcing has lead to a decline in moral such that many employees are convinced that they are no longer stakeholders or part of a meaningful team.

job_title: Flight Attendant in San Francisco, CA
pros: International and Domestic travel benefits for self and family. Flight benefits are dependent on whether there is additional space available on the aircraft. They are called "Stand-By" tickets (unconfirmed seats... you get to the gate and put your name on a list... then ONLY if there is space available... you will get assigned a seat/ ticket). Total cost of flights for self and a very select number of primary beneficiaries(I had 3) will cost you approximately 10-15% of ticket price. This percentage can change depending on where you are flying to. I paid $150 for a one way ticket to Tokyo.
cons: You do not get to directly choose your base location from ALL of the United bases! When you are in training you will be given a list of bases with available flight attendant openings. We were given 6 choices of locations around the United States and asked to rank our preferences. Then when we received our base assignments our entire training group was sent to only 2 of the 6  bases. We were told we could transfer within 6 months. Although this is true... if the base you are wanting to work out of does not have openings you will not be able to go there until space becomes available. Some places have a transfer waiting list of 1,000+ people. All transfers are based on seniority. Also, Flight Attendant Pay does not change whether you are based out of SFO (higher cost of living) or Houston (lower cost of living). Having experienced being based out of both base locations; I can definitely say that a salary of $1,600 a month while living in the bay area should be illegal.

job_title: Flight Attendant in San Francisco, CA
pros: If you like to meet new people everyday and fly to places you might never travel to, this is a perfect job for you. You have to be flexible with your life style and miss important events in exchange for a busy schedule. The best benefit is the free tickets for your family. You will  be too tired to use them, but your parents will be so pleased. After several years you will begin to choose a schedule and a destination you would like to travel to. You will never meet a better group of coworkers. And you will love the smell of jet fuel in the morning.
cons: Long days of sitting at the airport.

job_title: Costumer Service Manager in Houston, TX
pros:
Benefits--medical and flight are both excellent
Management treats us with respect
Great close knit culture
Laid back and casual 
Empowered to solve problems on the spot
cons: Moral is going way down along with our customer service ratings since the merger.  Not sure if we are keeping the Continental Culture.  I was impressed with how quickly we recovered from Irene. We got back to normal in days not weeks.  I worry that United management is not customer focused and that the only goal now will be profit.  Clearly they undoing a lot of great things that Gordon Bethune did for the company

review_title: Before the merger, had potential to be a great company (Continental), since, most likely will fail.
pros:
Flight benefits (when you can fly)
Working for a Fourtune 500 company
Carrer experience and exposure in a highly visible company
cons:
Way too much politics and deception
Way too much nepotism and slighted favortism
Unfair compensation for work ethic/results
Culture and local economy/company changes for the worse while going through merger that most people in both communities were against

job_title: Ramp Service in San Francisco, CA
pros: The employees are great with genuine positive attitudes who really do care. Very wide range of ethnic groups that work well with each other. The company recognizes that there is a lot of improvements that are needed and they are on their way, Only time will tell.
cons: Local Management is a "homeboy" group who only look out for themselves. The lack of respect and communication make it very difficult to achieve our goals everyday. Local management do not have the information or idea of how to run a business.

pros: Fun work, great working with people, good people to work with for the most part, traveling for free is obviously the biggest perk. Good pay for an easy job.
cons: I am a lower level employee, which means my job is constantly on the verge of layoffs, furloughs, etc.  Thoroughly poisonous relationship between upper management, lower management, and frontline workers.  Neither seems to trust the other at all, ungodly amounts of redtape to cut through to get even the most basic stuff done (i.e. correcting an incorrect paycheck).

review_title: Strong Network with some work to do.
pros: Fast paced. I always find the challenge to keep my job interesting and no day is ever the same at the airport.
cons: POLITICS from within as well as silly objectives that don't actually increase performance. The culture at the airport is also in shambles. It also appears the company would rather choose the cheaper option than make the more sensible and efficient one. The technology the company uses also lends to a decrease in efficiency and therefore the ontime performance continues to be middle of the pack if not the worst of the majors.

pros: typical airline. No better, no worse than most.
cons: They spend WAY too much time and money worried about a paperclip missing or a small piece of paper not put with a report that they say is needed to double and triple check that everything is right. I get redundancy, but their financial controls process wastes probably about a fourth of the money they take in on baggage and other fees!!

job_title: Aircraft Maintenance Tech in San Francisco, CA
pros: All of the reasons that Attracted me to the airlines: Flight benefits, Medical insurance, Pension, and wages. Flight benefits were wonderful, you could literally show up at an airport and get on stand-by almost anytime. The corporate culture was pleasant and like a big family.
cons: All of the Pros above no longer exists or it's value greatly diminished. Now it's impossible to get on a fight stand-by, and if you do get on, it is a middle seat in economy. Medical insurance is reduced at every contract. Our pension was dumped on the PBGC when the company filed for bankruptcy. Our wages are not keeping up with the economy.

review_title: Good Job But every rose has its thorns
job_title: Flight Attendant in San Francisco, CA
pros: Unionized Job. Guaranteed Pay per Month. Flight Benefits, health, vision and dental benefits, life insurance, 401K are just a few perks. All personality types to work with and most of all, the great adventure of seeing the world and the country.
cons: Poor management. Unhappy and divided workforce. Regardless of an industry leading contract, unhappy people from one former subsidiary are always trying to cause trouble.

pros: A great company to work for that treats it's employees with respect. You can grow within the company. The benefits outweigh the cons.
cons: The first 5 years of your life belong to the company. You will make less then $1,400 a month for the first 4 years. The newly hired flight attendants have a high turn over.

pros: There are lots of opportunities to grow. Every day you hear about someone moving up. Management seems humble and realistic. They know that United wasn't always the best airline and they are trying really hard to change it. The dress code in many non-customer-facing departments is business casual which makes for a relaxed atmosphere.
